description:
One of my new favorite restaurants in Chinatown! I tried it for the first time a month ago when my mom suggested it, and we had no expectations, so we were pleasantly surprised!

Spicy Numbing Beef Tendon ($7.95) - oh my goodness, SO delicious. Perfect texture of the tendons, great flavor, nice big pieces and awesome portion. Will order this every time I come here from now on.
Guiling Rice Noodle Soup ($9.95) - also SO delicious. I really didn't expect much from this but the broth was really flavorful, a little spicy and a little sour. The consistency of the rice noodles was great and I enjoyed this very much. 
Tempting Hot Pot - Combination, Chinese Herb Flavor (forgot the price) - this was good too! Didn't blow me away like the other two did, but still tasty and had a good amount of ingredients in it. Came on a burner that stayed strong throughout the meal. 

Service was whatever, but I have low expectations for Chinatown. Interior is clean and decor is nice. There is a great hot sauce on all the tables so don't forget about that. Definitely excited to come back again to try some other dishes (but still order the beef tendon)!
author: Nicole M.

description:
I'm going to try to keep my personal opinions out of this, here we go! 
If you like spices and alot of flavor going on in your mouth come to spicy king!
I shared the Fried rice and duck boiling pot with my mom (could probably comfortably feed a 3rd person) so the portions were great/family size. 
 I'm Mexican so I'm used to the typical Mexican heat, spices, and chilies. Duck Boiling Pot-There was lots of unfamiliar spice and heat-different then what I know which was great and all but the duck meat was cooked on the bone, with the fat still on. Which personally isn't the way I like my meat prepared. It was a bummer because you really had to work around the bone and fat, and after working through it there was hardly any meat to my pieces (unless my mom got to them before me ;)) So just imagine the scene you're doing the spicy pant with your tongue trying to gnaw your way to some meat LOL 
Fried rice was some of the best I've ever had (a little on the salty side) just how I like it-super flavorful 
The service lacked a bit of.. refinement the waittresses stood near our table the whole time we were there and didn't seem to do it for any beneficial reason, just mainly as a space to chitchat.  

I'd definitely be back! Although I'd be less adventurous and stick to the usuals Beef broccoli, chow mein, fried rice
author: Deanna H.

description:
I marked down stars based on the service.

Food recommendations: house cold noodles, numbing noodles, and house fried rice.
 
Service rant: I've been here a couple of times now and the service has been alright until recently. I came here with my boyfriend a few days ago since this is our to go spot whenever we are in Chinatown and when we were done eating our food and asked for the check. Instead of putting the check down and letting me look at the bill to get out my card to pay, the waitress simply just held it out and said to me it's going to be $25.00. I wasn't given time to go over and look at my bill, only a quick glance. After that when I got my card back to sign, another waitress came and was rushing to get back the check that I signed. I wasn't even done signing yet and she kept rushing us and saying how she really needed this bill and quickly took it. Overall it was really rude. Keep in mind that restaurant wasn't even packed at the time I went..

Food: Besides the service, the food is pretty good here. My go to orders are usually the numbing noodles and their house fried rice but I recently tried their house cold noodles and it was so good!

Numbing noodles- if you are a fan of spicy, you would like this. Like the name, you get a little numbing feeling on your tongue from the chili and spice. It's covered in this chili oil and overall it's really good. 
Cold noodles- Even though I usually get the numbing noodles I think I like these noodles more. You also get a lot so it's worth the price and it's also delicious.
House fried rice- this is probably my favorite fried rice I've had in a restaurant. It tastes better than most fried rice I've had in the Chinese restaurants I've been to. 
Explosive chicken- It was okay. It was kind of like popcorn chicken/ chicken nuggets but a little spicier. A little saltier than most chicken nuggets/fried chicken.
Kung pao chicken- need to eat this was rice otherwise it's too salty to eat because the sauce is flavorful. 
Cucumber side dish- it was sour and I personally did not enjoy it.
Overall I recommend the food but the service is sometimes off.
author: Kochamon S.

description:
It is a 3.5-star review. The food quality for my visit could only 3 stars. The spicy lamb chops are very salty and oily. Also, the majority of them are fat instead of a combination of lean meat and fat. At least 60% are fat, not meat. Maybe some people prefer this style lamb chops, I am not the big fun of fat. I am so upset with the food quality.

The waiter could realize 4/5 stars. Everyone is friendly and professional. I reported that my lamb chops are too salty. The waiter helped request re-processing quickly. Unfortunately, it is still kind of salty and too oily.
author: Xuan Z.

description:
Despite the service or lack of service, I'm still a fan. I was here with my dining partner 2015. Coming back for another visit and was craving spice, we landed here again. We came for lunch, upon arrival it was crowded. all front tables we taken. We were shown to the back tables that were private. Just then I had the feeling we were going to be the forgotten children,,, and I was RIGHT!

After we were seated it took a bit to get our menus which then they took our drink order right away. Our beers we ordered came, and at that point I made the server stay to take our food order which was the Pork Belly in Spicy Garlic Sauce appetizer and the Spicy Garlic Flavored Prawns. The dishes seem to take forever as 2 tables next to use with a party of 6 that sat after us were getting their dishes. Finally we got our 2 dishes and I have to say they were excellent. Perfect heat, the right amount of garlic and the quantity of each dish was good. Our server never came to check on us, ask us how our food was or even to see if we wanted another beer. Then the wait for the server to come back with the check which I then had to get up and ask for it not to mention I had to go back to the cash register wait for someone to process the check.

Atmosphere: typical Chinatown Chinese restaurant. Service: very OK to poor. Food: Very Very Good. I will try other places though next visit.
author: Melody K.

description: Their spicy fish fillet was really good but their much advertised Chongqing Hot and Numbing Noodle was too plain without much taste. As a result, I'm giving them 3 out of 5
author: Jackson H.

description:
Be prepared with the crazy spicy dishes here, they don't mess around with the chilies that they put in the dishes. 

We came here on a Friday night, and the place was oddly empty. We heard that usually this place tends to get crowded during dinners. 

Our Taiwanese friends ordered the food for us, he ordered 6 dishes for the 4 of us and surprisingly we finished them all! All I remembered about the orders were spicy chicken, mixed meat hotpot, lamb skewers, veggies, noodle and fish. We also got the plum juice to help counter the spiciness (worked a little). All of the dishes were delicious!
author: Nathania Y.

description:
This is the best Sichuan restaurant known to man... well at least in San Francisco. Plus there is this bitchin Harley Davidson inside the entrance. Why? Because the owner loves his motorcycle, that's why. And maybe, in some small way, having a motorcycle with a one foot wide contact patch makes the spicy food even better. Come in and try it and you'll see what I mean. And take some nice selfies with you and the motorcycle. 

You're welcome!
author: Lancer K.

description: I was visiting friends in SF and we decided to come here. We got a large fish boil and all the small dishes to add in like you would hot pot. We also got Chicken with Explosive Chili Pepper and it was so good! The spicy was numbing, very authentic, and flavorful. It was sweat inducing, but totally worth every bite. We shared with four people and it was more than enough food for everyone.
author: Rona S.

description: Surprised to get a seat quickly. Friendly staff. Clean and nicely decorated facility. I only had one dish, but I liked it. It could gave been hotter, but it wasn't bad. The price was excellent. $10 for a bowl of noodles I couldn't finish was perfect. Though, there could have been a bit more beef. Go and enjoy!
author: Ian D.

description:
4 stars because I didn't try everything on the menu and other people's foods was looking pretty goods.


I came here looking for that dope, numbing, hot oil.
Also have been looking for dope dandan mian. 
No luck tonight and no luck in SF so far. 
Let me know if you have recs for a legit, dry dandan mian.

Spiciness scale: (descending spice) 
1. Chongqing hot oil noodles
2. Wonton hot oil 
3. Dandan mian

I wouldn't recommend the last two.
author: Olivia P.

description: There was no wait on a Wednesday , around 1:30pm for lunch so my son and I came in. Having been to China a couple of times made us remember how good food is served fresh and quick! Here, Service is quick, the waitresses are very friendly.  It's the nearest to an authentic Szechuan cuisine!  A must try restaurant in Chinatown !
author: Nieves O.

description: Most of their dishes are delicious and pretty authentic. Their twice cooked pork is okay but for some reason they put a lot of tofu in it. Not a big fan of that here. The pork intestines with picked mustard (or really prepared any other way) hits the spot every time. I also like that their spice levels are pretty high.
author: Arka G.

description:
So good!!! Took care of us right away with a reservation and waitress was super sweet! 
The place is also decorative & very welcoming!! Loved it!!!
author: Emalie D.

description:
I kept hearing about "the good Szechuan restaurant at Waverly Place".
so I came here and ordered two among other things that Szechuan cooking are famous for.
I ordered "Dan Dan Noodle" and "Fish Fillet in Flaming Chili Oil".
you agree with me? if you know Szechuan Cuisine, you know that those two are some of the dishes that the region are known for beside kung pao chicken, mapo tofu, beef cumin, lamb cumin, dried beef in chili oil, explosive chicken in chili peppers, etc etc ..
you know what I mean.
first of all, not enough Szechuan Peppercorn only dried Chili Peppers floating around the dish (fish fillet in flaming chili oil) and it's not spicy nor numbing at all, it's more like just garnish.
so I ordered the Dan Dan Mien (Noodle), it's the same. 
I couldn't taste the Authenticity of the Szechuanese ingredients in the bowl.
there was no depth at all.

and then, ..
I heard the chef spoke to each other in Cantonese.
I know because I sat at the bar and it face directly to the kitchen, and my parents are Cantonese.
author: Rudy H.

description: The food is really yummy. But the service is off the top bad. The restaurant has a bunch of empty seats, but the waitresses cannot get people seated for like 20minutes. Don't know what's going on.
author: LinQian S.

description: Spicy food, soothing tea and beautiful ambiance! Love this gem place with minimal wait time!
author: Sonali C.

description:
I've always wanted to come here because I love spicy food. However, after eating here once, I will never come back. There are better restaurants in Chinatown for a lot cheaper than what this place charges. I feel like it's a very gimmicky place, boasting that they have top chefs. 

The dishes we got were expensive and disappointing for the price. At around $15 a plate, you expect quality and dishes that are shrouded with cheap veggies or meat with mostly fat. 

We got the following
-Lotus roots with garlic: This was good but def not worth the money
-Green onion pancake: Greasy, meh.
-Noodle soup: Bland
-Salt and pepper ribs: these were terrible, literally no meat at all, it was all fat that we had to trim, in the end you are left with a quarter size piece of meat. Disappointing.

Save your money. Go somewhere else. Service isn't that great either. Water refills and getting something as simple as a bill takes forever.
author: Kelly L.

description: Amazing food, traditional and great service. We got the mandarin dinner for 3, and now i can't wait to co back. The sweet and sour pork was the best and the chow mein was chart topping!
author: Zach T.

description:
This authentic style restaurant is located in Chinatown. It has a great ambience and judging by the crowd it seems to be doing really well. 

We had to wait for 10 mins and were seated promptly. The staff is very efficient and expects you to be quick with your order. The tables turn around quick. They serve hot tea on the house ( which I love with my meal). 

We tried chicken stir fry, vegetables of the day and white rice. The food was good and the spice was on the higher side. The flavours were good and it's slightly greasy , not too much tho. The portions are good for sharing.  

I recommend this place if you are craving Asian flavours and some spice.
author: Shivani B.

description: Beef tendon here is amazing. Don't pass this place up. If you've never had it you must try it. Perfect blend of spicy and savory. I come here every time I'm in San Francisco because the beef tendon is one of my all-time favorite foods!
author: Pete W.

description:
Pretty authentic Szechuan restaurant with quick service. 

Combination flaming pot: 5/5 love this dish! It has lots of ingredients: lotus root, intestine, shrimp, fish, corn and etc. Spicy and flavorful. It went well with rice.
Pork intestine with Szechuan pickled mustard: 5/5 I preferred pickled mustard marinated intestine over stirred fried because it's less oily. The intestine was soft, silky and flavorful. 
Dry sautéed string greens: 4/5 pretty standard and rich in flavor 
Spicy eel with flaming chili oil: 2/5 too oily and salty without much eel meat.
author: Cynthia W.

description: I didn't give it 5 Stars only because I didn't try the rest of the food my boyfriend did like the sweet and sour chicken but as for me the hot and sour soup was the best one I've ever had. I couldn't stop eating it and I even went back during my short trip to San Francisco.
author: Valerie G.

description:
It was a very cold night, and it was perfect for spicy food. We were staying in Union Square and knew that Chinatown would be the perfect place to get spicy food. Found the place through yelp, and because it was President's Day, some of the ones with "higher ratings" were closed so we decided to take a chance on this one.

We arrived around 6:30 pm to a half empty restaurant, and as soon as we were seated, a waitlist started to form immediately! We got lucky before hitting rush hour. 

We ordered the cucumber salad to start, my husband had the spicy beef noodle soup and I had the Tan tan noodles. The cucumber salad was tangy and savory, a very nice start to the meal (and a nice cooling contrast to the spicy noodle dishes we ordered) 

I was almost disappointed when I saw the glob of noodles arrive, it looked like it was hauled out of starchy noodle water and looked stuck together. It took a while to mix my tan tan noodles together, but as soon as all the spices and oil got mixed in between, the noodles clung to the spices and minced pork.  My husband, who has just recently developed a liking to Asian cuisine, thoroughly enjoyed his beef noodle soup and claimed it was better than our local beef noodle soup spot in LA. The dishes were spicy but not too spicy, the Sichuan peppercorns add a very interesting spice depth to the dish that makes it very enjoyable.
author: Angela L.

description:
Super long wait for the food. We waited more than 30 mins for two of the cold dish appetizer, which should be prepared and ready to serve long time ago. Our baby was crying because he was starving. They took more the an hour to serve the lo mein noodles because they only have one chef working in the kitchen during weekend. I guess they should hire more cooks then. 

Horrible customer service. They automatically charged for 18% tip when we only have 4 adults and one baby, and they put down 6 guests on the ticket in order to charge tip. One of the waitress is super rude to us when we ask for a plastic spoon for our baby. 

Wouldn't recommend, at least I'm not going back.
author: Annie L.

description:
My partne and I went here for lunch, actually we were walking through Chinatown and one of the employees handed us a menu and escorted us to the door. I loved it. The Cross Bridge Rice noodles were delicious as were the veggie spring rolls. Definitely something to  check out when you are in the bay area.

My only complaint was the heat from the kitchen really affects the dining experience.
author: Maria P.

description: One of the first place I got to know the Sichuan peppercorn. The chicken with chilli's, Dan Dan noodles, ma po tofu, were all game changing-ly delicious for an Oregonian like me!
author: Thomas R.

description:
My Chinese New Year tradition is to celebrate in China Town, SF, and that usually starts with a dinner before everything kicks off. My boyfriend and I showed up first this year, before any friends, so we had a romantic dinner together, at a table we shared with two strangers. It was actually really fun. We have an upcoming trip to China/Thailand so we really got excited as we celebrated over delicious bowls of steaming food, including:

Large hot and sour soup $10.95
Cashew chicken $9.95
Pork fried rice $9.95
Pot stickers (6) $6.95
Tsing Tao $4.50
2 x large sake $8.50 (each)
to-go box and bag $0.70

Service was fantastic and it really started off a great night and a wonderful Lunar New Year celebration. What a wild party it was!! (Note: we found this restaurant on our phones and it appeared as Uncle's Cafe on Google.)
author: Amy S.

description:
I came here on a weekday evening with a friend and we were seated on the very inside of the restaurant, near what is presumably the private area. I sort of knew what I wanted prior to coming in, but I wanted to look at the menu one last time, before ordering. I narrowed it down between the Cross Bridge Rice Noodle and the Hot and Sour Noodle Soup with Port Intestines, both dishes that I have never had before. I eventually went with the hot and sour noodle soup because it was three dollars cheaper than the cross bridge rice noodle. After deciding on our respective dishes, it took a while for the waiter to come take our order since it was very crowded and there was limited staff to field all the orders. 

After our dishes arrived, I went ahead and sample the broth. I felt a jolt of sourness running through me and was surprised at the level of sourness this dish had. A bit stunned, I then moved on to the pork intestines. The pork intestines were pretty quite soft and chewy. There was also a generous helping of peanuts and the bamboo shoots as seen in the picture, and I personally have no opinion on them since every spoonful I'm constantly reminded of the sourness of the soup. Glass noodles would not have been my first choice of noodles if I had to pick, but I don't think I can fault the store on that front since I chose the dish. 

Toward the end of the meal, I was having significant buyer's remorse and felt that I should have ponied up the extra three dollars for the cross bridge rice noodle instead. It got to the point where I couldn't finish the broth, which I am normally able to do. I know I said this before, but I severely underestimated the sourness of this dish, as it overpowered everything else in the dish. One takeaway from this would be that I don't really have that high of a tolerance for sourness, and have to think about more about ordering sour dishes going forward. Anyways, I had to make an effort again to flag down the waitress for our check and we were on our way out back into the cold night. If I were to come back, it would be for the cross bridge rice noodle since that's the only thing on the menu that seems interesting to me.
author: Nelson X.

description: If you like hot and spicy this is the place to go. If you have people in your party than doesnt like spicy there some stuff on menu that are not spicy. Like the Fish and ginger sauce, yumminess is what i call it.
author: Ron D.

description: Spicy beef noodle soup is a must try if you go to SF.   I get the spicy beef noodle soup every time I go to SF and it never disappoints
author: Bjorn H.

description: I went with my friends to have dinner there recently. We were seated after about 10 minutes of waiting. When we sat down and decided what to order we waited another half hour until someone decided to take our order, keep in mind the place was practically empty. We were not asked for drinks and out plates were placed on a stack at the end of the table with the cups on top of them. We waited patiently and ate. When done we waited almost 45 minutes before even getting our bill. We didn't get any quality service and when the bill came they tried including an 18% tip into our total. We also noticed when other people walked in after us their tables were neatly set up then they were seated. I don't know if it was just us, but my friend group and I don't think we'll be going back. The food was alright and could feed more people than all of us.
author: Maria M.

description: The service was terrible. We walked out after being snubbed by the hostess and then waiting for several minutes after being seated without service. At one point the server even brought dishes, but put them on the table without acknowledging anyone at the table or even saying hello before disappearing again. 5 minutes later we gave up and left.
author: Lacey C.

description: It is said to be closed at 10:30. They no longer accept people at 9:45. Why not call in advance? No. they never pick up phone.
author: ZY Y.

description:
Service 2/5
Flavor 3/5
Spiciness 3/5
Value 3/5
Menu 5/5
Ambiance 4/5

Requested spicy but it just wasn't there. Flavors were good, but not great. Clean bathrooms.
author: Turkey B.

description: I love Schezuan food! This place is pretty good! There are a lot of choices in the city but this is up there for me. We ordered the explosive chicken which I thought was amazing. The pork in garlic sauce was average. There are lots more to try and the menu has plenty of pics to make it easy to order.
author: Vinayak P.

description:
Finding something to eat in Chinatown was a challenge because we wanted to eat everything. After talking to a few locals, we decided on a Szechuan type meal. We stumbled upon Spicy King and immediately were drawn to the variety of 'new' Chinese food. 

We ordered about 10 different dishes and each one was amazing. If you try this place, please order the Lo Mein noodles, you will not be disappointed. 

Oh, and their spicy sauce is TO DIE FOR!
author: Jackie V.

description: Z and Y was too damn busy so we couldn't get our spicy boiled fish fix satisfied. Luckily Spicy King was open for another hour and they came through something fierce! Also green beans ruled.
author: Rob R.

description: I love this place. Usually order from Uber eats here. Great authentic variety. Love the authentic taste
author: Ender M.

description: The food quality not bad, but the rice cooked really bad. I have no idea why they want us pay $ for the rice.
author: Xiaoxiao L.

description:
I loved going to this Spicy King for my lunch while it started opening in Chinatown about 2 yrs or 3 yrs ago. After several months,after they rise the prices little bit I also noticed quality and quantity of their dishes dropped dramatically.  For example,I loved one of their noodles that got nice spicy soup and very good bargain deal for 7.99. Later not just they asked 2 dollars more but delivered a terrible noodle that came with pure hot water instead spicy soup. They simply mixed some hot water with their noodles.  That made the noodles tasted terrible bad . They also screwed my another favorite which is beef noodle. It got some delicious big beef meat that was big as 2/3 size of my hand and then later for the same price,a same beef noodle,what I found were some small piece of beef as small as my finger and also very few pieces. For another of my favorite dishes, I was asking to pay 2 dollar more and got only half of what I used to get before.
I stopped going to this Spicy King after they couldn't keep up what they were good at till I visited them again 2 months ago. And they fcked it again. Another overpriced noodle simply mixed tasteless hot water with little meats.  I am done with this Spicy King for rest of my life. Indeed,it keeps expanding to get new restaurants opening in Bay Area but they totally provide shitty bad dishes now.
author: Ji Jin Z.

description:
I'm giving this five stars on food and four stars on service. The food? Amazingly spicy, absolutely sweat-inducing, and just overall exactly what we showed up for. I can't tell you the names of the dishes off the top of my head, unfortunately, since my family ordered in Chinese, but rest assured the numerous dishes we had were delicious. Service was decent. Our waitress was a little curt (to be fair, there were many people, so this is understandable). We made a mistake with the bill at the end and she was rather condescending when trying to explain our mistake. 

tl;dr: Food's really great and despite our waitress, I would come back again if I craved more spiciness.
author: Kel M.

description: Can only speak to the take-out. I got the mixed dry pot take-out and it was a complete mush. The meat (couldn't tell which kind) was cut into ginormous chunks and did not taste fresh. I ended up tossing most of it. For an entree that came to ~25 bucks (and no rice) this was a major disappointment
author: Nancy L.

description: Great food and good service; however, charging customers $.30 per container ($ 0.10 per bag) really bothers me. (This applies to both dine-in and to-go)
author: Elaine Y.

description: Great! Great! Great! We met friends from out of town, asked Yelp for help - this place had good reviews so we went. Total win. Well, pretty much all good - skip the short ribs - loved the other 6 dishes!
author: Mike W.

description: Pretty solid food if you are into spicy oily Sichuan food The service was good enough for a chinese restaurant.
author: Eric L.

description:
not real szechuan cuisine
too sweet but not spicy

plus，both of us who ate there suffer from stomache the next day
author: 以欢

description: This place is definitely worth the wait if you come here during busy times. I've been here at lunch and there's usually not a wait. The service is quick but the food can take a while to cook. I love the mapo tofu here but everything I've had at Spicy King is great. If you don't like spicy food, go elsewhere.
author: Annita K.

description: Good Chinese Kitchen! So spicy food, great experience! the waitress brought a dish that was not ordered, and there was an insignificant dispute, in the consequence they removed this dish from the account
author: Rinat B.

description:
Note that we asked for reduced salt on everything, but everything was still delicious. Garish decor that is somehow endearing.


---- APPETISERS ----

葱油饼: 4.5 stars
As good as any you'll find in this city.

Cucumber salad: 4 stars
$7 but a pretty big portion and well seasoned, yummy.

红油抄手 Chili Oil Dumplings: 3.5 stars
I've had better.


---- VEGETABLES ----

Beech Mushrooms 茶树菇: 5 stars
Unique and flavourful. Full of umami! I've never had anything like it. Cooked with pork belly and onions. Slightly salty but forgiven.

String Beans:


---- MEAT AND NOODLES ----

麻辣牛肉面 Spicy Beef Noodles: 4.5 stars

担担面 Dan Dan Noodles: 4 stars
One of the better ones in the city.

孜然牛 Cumin Beef: 4.5 stars
I love cumin. Beef is tender.

麻婆豆腐: 2 stars
Nothing special.

辣子鸡: 5 stars
Be warned there are two versions of this deep-fried chicken dish. The first version has lots of bones in it and is overcooked and costs much more (apparently a delicacy with 黄鸡 and the locals like to eat the bones). The second has only meat with no bones, crispy shell, tender meat, tasty, and is apparently cheaper.
author: Letitia L.

description: This place was really good , especially the mala chicken.
author: Hwang Hah J.

description:
Came here with friends to try out Szechuan food. I've had szechuan before so this isn't really a new thing to me. 

Nothing really stood out for me in terms of food. Maybe we got the safer dishes? 
Service was blah. I guess not non-Chinese people friendly. 

I need to come here with people who's willing to try more legit stuff.
author: Claire J.

description:
Good spot for Szechuan. Tried the dry fried string beans and they were excellent. Blistered on the outside, good amount of building spice, and salty. For vegetarians- there is a fair amount of choice (eggplant, tofu, noodles). 

My boyfriend tried the Pig Feet and they looked spicy AF but he enjoyed them!
author: Samantha K.

description:
Horrible service, horrible customer service. Took 10 minutes before they even noticed us to be seated we were told to hold on twice. We got sat and they gave us ONE menu for three people. And some service is so bad of course I took another 10 minutes for us to ask for two additional menus. We were ready to order and it took 10 more minutes to wave down a waitress eventually my friend went to the cashier and said we were ready to order, they came 5 min later. Food was not good, you can find way better elsewhere, overpriced. They never came and asked how our food was or just check in. Tried to get a refill for tea and of course they aren't attentive. At this point we're already fed up and just wanted to leave and pay the bill. I've worked in the service industry and understand how much waitresses get paid but there needs to be actual work done to earn the tips. Thus, since we did more work waiving down to get served I decided not to tip. The waitress had the guts to chase after us into the rain and say that the boss says we NEED to tip. I am not sure if they thought we were tourist and trying to rip us off or what cause I was born and raised in the US and it is not against the law not to tip. At this point we were already beyond fed up so I tipped and left. Will never return, not recommended. Please spend your money elsewhere.

Update: just saw another review where they automatically charge you a "service fee of 15%" on your bill. Now I probably tipped 30% at this point. I think it needs to be clearly labeled somewhere or told to us if there is already a service fee in the meal usually only groups of 6 or more have an automatic tip in my 24 years of life. Either way never returning.
author: Alison C.

description: Tan Tan noodles are a must! Service was great. We were seated right away and food came out with in 5 minutes. Food was hot and fresh and very tasteful!
author: Kristina O.

description: This place was great. Lots of locals, delicious preparation, very fast service. Waitress was very helpful in making selections. We're satisfied!
author: Bob H.

description: Pretty solid Sichuan food. We got the green beans and fish hot pot. The dishes weren't as spicy as I expected, which is probably a good thing. Definitely get some beer or sake to go with it.
author: Kevin R.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in Chinatown. It's authentic so expect the efficiency without frills. Come here every visit to San Francisco. If you love Schezuan and can handle a little spice, this is the place for you. Just look for the big Harley by the bar upon entering. Favorites are the explosive chicken, chicken fried rice, and jalapeño flavored century eggs. Mmmm.
author: Leanna L.

description: Disappointed.  I think this place has the potential to be awesome.  Ordered two noodle soaps and the spare ribs appetizer.  The spare rib actually was tasty but it came out room temp.  I cant tet over that it has been searing around all day and they served it without warming it up.  The noodles were unremarkable.  Overall, it was a blah experience. Wouldn't return nor recommend.  Hopefully they make the necessary changes and give dinner a better experience.
author: Duke L.

description:
Definitely coming back with a few more people so I can try some of the larger dishes. 

Flavor was good. Reminded me of my days in China. The spice level is definitely toned down compared to the mainland. Good nonetheless

I'm a sucker for the cucumbers. Lightly flavored but tasty
Lamb skewers meaty but included some fat to balance
3 cup chicken was on the sweeter side
Hunan dry noodles had a nice light kick to it
Jalapeño preserved eggs is a fun dish to try. 

Will update the next time I visit. 

Seating is pretty limited. So prepare for a wait.
author: Lyman C.

description: Awful service I have ever seen before. Honestly, food not bad, but not good, too oily. But service is like a trash, bullshit. Will not come again. The waitress deserve to be a waitress forever. Disgusted waitress ever. Why you guys think you deserve a tips from me? Trash!
author: Yonnie W.

description: Get the noodles with peas and meat sauce. The sauce is fan-TA-stic. $9.95.
author: Kristen S.

description: It was okay food... spring roll soggy, Mongolian beef greasy. Sweet and sour soup ... okay
author: Jette Erick U.

description:
I ordered the Kung pow chicken.  The food was OK but felt it lacking in enough vegetables and was swimming in sauce.  

I also found it be expensive for what was provided.
author: Dennis W.

description: We ordered takeout on Chinese New Year. It was very busy and we ordered the pancakes, bbq lamb skewers, couples beef, sweet and sour pork, chicken fried rice, salt and pepper shrimp, and tan tan noodles. Once we received the food, we hurried back to eat at the hotel and found out that didn't receive the tan tan noodles or the salt and pepper pork. Other than that, all of the food was tasty and the wait wasn't very long.
author: A. W.

description:
Not impressed. 

Stopped in here while detouring through china town. It was able to accommodate our large group so why not?

The tea was ok
Spring rolls were awesome. 
Rice was, eh. 

We ordered a few different things and nothing really stood out as better than the other. 

Spicy? Eh, it was only if I caught something with more peppers. 

I have read that Chinese food in San Francisco isn't that great anyway and after having some, I would agree. 

Don't expect to be blown away.
author: Christopher R.

description: Great vegetarian food! Drove all the way from San Jose to China Town for their spicy numbing noodles  and their shredded potatoes.
author: Amrita S.

description: Ordered Couple's Delight (not very flavorful compared to the other Sichuan Restaurants), Garlic Cucumber (no sesame oil, but lots of vinegar), Sweet and Sour Short Ribs (not sour at all, super sweet), Spicy Chili (not bad, but not super good either). Not worth the 30 min wait! Although it's owned by the same owner of Chongqing Xiaomian, the same dishes here taste a lot worse than Chongqing Xiaomian. Will not return.
author: Rachel C.

description:
Boy did I had a hankering for Szechuan...yeah yeah, I know, what's new?!...so I looked to yelp! for guidance while in SF. It's true that I almost always avoid places with less a than 4 star rating unless of course there isn't anything else around my hotel but after reading a couple of the reviews it seemed to me this spot was of 4 star caliber (perhaps more), at least as far as the food was concerned. So I took a chance, what can I say, I like living dangerously.
   After seeing many a drool worthy pictures of the dan dan noodles, I was fixated. I rolled up solo and was quickly sat at the bar. The biggest challenge was looking through the extensive menu to find what I already knew I was going to order. I ordered and after what seemed like almost no time at all came a gigantic bowl of heaven. My first thought was... "How in the world am I going to finish all of this!?" I would later find myself scraping the bottom of the bowl for any remaining morsels to keep the taste in my mouth. Point is...holy moly was the broth tasty, the meat succulent, perfectly balanced numbing spice with the freshness of the cabbage hiding under all those noodles. GAAAHHHHHH was it good and the price was extremely reasonable.
   So all I can wonder is..."why only 3.5 stars?" when this was sooo dang delectable. Sure, the service is straight to the point. The no fuss kind you get from the best Asian restaurants in my opinion. You just have to let them know when you need the check or more water etc. This bothers some folks, but to me...no big deal because servers were constantly present, buzzing around taking orders and delivery food and most importantly the food spoke for itself. Next time I'm in town coming back will be a no brainer. Don't make the mistake I almost made and give this place a try.
author: Cory W.

description:
I have never been to a place where the waitress came back to my table after paying to tell me my tip wasn't enough.
However, that is exactly what happened to me at Spicy King! 
This, even after we found a hair in the food. She came back and asked for 5 more dollars! 
They better enjoy that extra 5 dollars because it is the last penny Spicy King will ever get from me! 
Awful!
author: Allie Z.

description: We were looking for a place, and daughter isn't a spicy food fan, but it was late. They seated us quickly, and had attentive service.  I had the Hunan pork, m'lady had the garlic eggplant, and lass had the salt & pepper shrimp. All were done nicely. A tad oily perhaps, but tasty and filling.  Definitely a good experience.
author: Clark Q.

description:
I love a nice spicy lunch to help energize me for the rest of the workday; works better than coffee!  Though I really like Z&Y for Szechuan, their popularity makes getting a table difficult sometimes.  Spicy King is a little off the tourist path which means seating is easier; also it feels like some of the dishes might even be spicier.  A good way to get your chili fix.

Chicken w/ Explosive Chili Pepper: Despite all the chilis, it's not that hot if you don't eat the dried chilis (which don't have a good texture anyway, since they're dried).  The chicken chunks are pretty large, like a bite or two per piece.  And they seem more generous with chicken portion than at other Szechuan places.  Lots of perfumey Szechuan pepper taste (which are from the little peppercorns, not the long dried chilis).  A little fried chicken overload for one person, but great to share.

Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodles w/ Peas & Meat Sauce: Thin crinkly noodles, like ramen, in an oily chili sauce.  It wasn't quite numbing, but it was appreciably hot.  The bland cabbage pieces were a nice palate cleanser between bites.  I wasn't really feeling the peas since they seemed like the canned kind (or maybe frozen), but definitely not fresh out of the pod.  The minced meat was nice, but a small portion.
author: Adam B.

description: Ordinary food. Pricey as well. You would find similar food at any other restaurant out there.  Service is also poor
author: S D.

description:
Another popular trend in Chinese cuisine besides hot pots is spicy food, specially Southwest Chinese regional style.  Szechuan is the most famous along with Guizhou.  Szechuan's capitol is Chengdu, most famous for its panda reserves.  
The recent trend that started a couple years back is numbing hot, a sensation that leaves a tingling sensation on your tongue and renders all flavors to be neutral (neither salty or sweet).  This is not my cup of tea and, for me, if you can't taste it, what's the point?!
The restaurant is known for their hot pots which is difficult for lunch, given most people are on a schedule workwise.  After studying their individual serving dishes, I decided to try their Tan Tan noodles (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=YzdsvLPG1YjkobZ7k0n8PQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) for $7.95.  
Eating this in my office, it was a bit difficult to mix the ingredients as most of the meat and sauce were on the bottom.  After eating my way down about 1/3rd of the way, I was able to better mix those with the cabbage.  The flavors weren't overly spicy but still had good enough heat.  The cabbage added a crunch to the noodle bounce and the minced meat pieces.
Yes, I would have this again.
My friend and I stopped for hot pot but there was an interruption so I'll withhold comment until I actually enjoy this here.
The chef apparently worked for the popular Z&Y on Jackson Street for some time before branching on his own. The original spot was the former location of Pot Sticker about half a block away on the other side of the street.  I've tried his other restaurant on Geary Blvd last year, coincidentally during the Warriors' finals' run.
For Chinatown old timers, most will remember this spot of the famed Uncle's Restaurant, where many of the political negotiations back in the day happened in the community.  This was a popular breakfast place for local business owners and family association officers for discussing situations and solving problems (ala Sun Wah Kue, Mary's, Jackson Café, etc.).
The ambiance is a bit dark in there with a few large tables and mostly two or four seat tables.  Checkout the "ride" in the front of the restaurant, which doesn't make much sense to me.
But I guess that's the thing about Chinatown... many things don't quite make sense here.
author: Mike C.

description: We ordered noodles and a live whole fish. The food was pretty good - a little too oily and salty for my taste though. Also, prices run pretty steep.
author: Jane H.

description: They recycle their chili oil and chili, I know that because I ordered a frog pot and I had 2 piece of chicken bone at the end, so nasty can't believe it
author: Sarah A.

description: We stumbled into this restaurant totally by accident. Loved it! Food is very spicy, but very delicious. The Lamb Skewer was super spicy! Ruined by taste buds.
author: Liz C.

description:
I love spicy food and this place did not disappoint.  I can't wait to go back again.  I went with someone from Chengdu and it got his stamp of approval as well.

They have a dish that consists of just jalapeños in some vinegary sauce which was probably the tastiest thing I had, although it wasn't particularly spicy.
author: Jason F.

description:
This is a great Sichuan restaurant in SF and 5 stars are based on the food, not on service. I'm from china and love spicy food and this place hits the spot. Yes it's less spicy that what you would find in Sichuan but the numbing spicy is authentic. 

You should not listen to those who gave shitty reviews based on cleanliness and service. If that's what you are looking for, definitely go elsewhere. If you want good authentic food, get some chongqing numbing noodles, couples delight, fish in chili oil or a flaming pot. It saddens me that people made the trek to this place and orders things like egg rolls or chow mein, and then gets disappointed with the "Chinese" food they got. Come with the expectation Sichuan spicy means numbing spicy. just because it's not the spicy you are used to doesn't mean you should rate it low and recommend others to go elsewhere.
author: Molly H.

description:
4/5/15: Just a quick look at reviews tells me many people misunderstand what this restaurant serves: authentic Chinese Szechuan (Sichuan) food.  Here's a quote from a 1 star review:

"However, be warn with both of these dishes the food is sitting in a pool of chili oil.  The chili oil is how they make everything spicy. It's so greasy. Yuck."

Obviously the reviewer has no idea what true Szechuan food is since the "pool of chili oil" is the hallmark of such cooking.  Many of the dishes mention a "numbing oil" referring to the fact that if done properly your mouth should feel somewhat numbed (to let you tolerate much hotter foods) as a result of the special pepper corns they use, yes, in a pool of oil.  Anyway, just wanted to point that out.

That said, I've had my fair share, including some really awesome ones in Monterey Park, and unfortunately this place isn't among the best, and is actually sub par...

1. Couple's Delight $7.95: This is the MUST HAVE for any Szechuan meal--the typical 2 or 3 foods (out of sliced beef, pig ear, and tripe) combined for an appetizer, hopefully with ton of numbness dished in.  In this case, they did the famous dish right.  Everything was super flavorful and rich.  8/10.

2. Chongqing Hot Numbing Spicy Noodle $7.95:  My girl was SUPER HAPPY to see this on the menu.  Even immigrating from China she has never had this dish and was looking forward to duplicating it.  Unfortunately, what they server was NOT IT.  Also, not hot or numbing at all.  -2/10.   Yes you read that right: NEGATIVE TWO / 10 for making a joke out of a famous dish.  -----2/10

3. Boiling Live Fish w/ Numbing Chili Oil $28.95: Sigh..... so, my girl and her friend immediately said this was not "live."  We even asked the waitress who confirmed they did use a live fish.  I dunno, maybe it was killed in the morning and they called it "live."  Personally, I thought the fish was okay, but was more disappointed that it was cheapass tilapia, the cheapest live fish you can get at Ranch 99!  For nearly $30, totally not even close to worth that chunk of change.  Taste-wise, again, I thought it was okay, but out of the humongoid pot, I think 2/3rds of it was chilli peppers and inedible filler.  Very little actual fish.  This is one of the most expensive items on their menu, so I warn you--DO NOT GET THIS.  2/10.

4. House Special Lamb Ribs $13.95: I LOVE ribs.  American.  Chinese.  Whatever.  And I've had ribs at other Szechuan places and I always love them.  But this one.... some pieces were okay, but most of the ribs were not intact, with half their meat ripped off.  The ones that were still one piece were good.  The rest was just lying in the dish.  Also, some of the lone pieces were super chewy and were barely swallowable.  Note, this is the cumin-flavored variation, not the bbq type.  2/10.

5. Chicken w/ Explosive Chili Pepper $13.95:  I thought this one was decent.  Pretty tender chicken to me with good pepper taste.  But the girls disagreed.  Anyway, for me, 5/10.

This restaurant just isn't as good as their average competitor.  Go elsewhere.

#chinese #szechuan #sichuan
author: Dean C.

description:
Take the road less traveled...by tourists...and find yourself here.

I wasn't sure that they would speak English, and my abilities in any dialect of Chinese are minimal.  It wasn't a problem, and no Chinese was necessary.

It wasn't really busy when I arrived, but the waitress came over to greet me.  She looked about the dining room, grabbed a towel and a menu, and seated me after cleaning a table for two.  I only needed one chair, despite my big mouth.

Given that they specialize in Sichuan food, I wanted to find something interesting.  I was friends with a Chinese family who owned a restaurant in Ohio, and they approximated Sichuan cuisine, but I've never had the food made with the real recipes.

I ordered the Hand-shredded cabbage, which was meant to be spicy.  I talked to waitress about it, and I mentioned tofu.  She showed me Mapo Tofu, which is a Shanghai-nese (I've been reminded by someone that it is Sichuan.  I don't know but I've had people from Shanghai claim it, also.) recipe that I really like but I was there for Sichuan food.  She suggested that I might like the Preserved Egg and Tofu appetizer.  I had asked for iced tea, as she had brought hot tea.  They didn't have any.  She also asked if I wanted steamed white rice.

When I returned from the restroom, she had brought ice water.  It wasn't long after that when she brought the appetizer, and fairly quickly, the main course arrived, along with steamed white rice.

Since I wasn't sure how anything but the rice should taste, I was pleased with all of it.  The appetizer was cold and the level of spice was mild.  The level of spice of the cabbage was a bit higher and there were many red peppers that had been cooked with the cabbage as well.  Is this typical?  I don't know.

I remember being told that Sichuan recipes were extremely spicy, and they had some tongue-numbing recipes, with the word "numbing" in the description.

I felt more secure as other Asians entered the restaurant.  I've been to a number of places where the tourists outweigh the local people, and it always gives me the feeling that the food isn't good enough.  I believe this place is good enough.
author: Nobuyuki S.

description: Explosive Chicken with Chili period!  A little spicy yes but that is what I crave while in SF Chinatown.
author: Anthony B.

description: Great decor. The 3 mix vegetables was very good! The spicy chicken was ok. We decided to try the Pork Belly. It was served at room temperature. We took one bite. We didn't like it one bit!! I've only sent 3 things back to a kitchen in my life and Spicy King charged us!! It's both rude and disrespectful to charge a dissatisfied customer. I won't ever come back to this place. I really thought San Fran would have good Chinese food but I've come to the conclusion there's good and bad food everywhere.
author: Jerry G.

description: incredible food, I am surprised the star rating for was restaurant was lower than I expected, it is much much better than all the other sze chuan food I have tried in sf, the food quality is superb and the price is pretty cheap, I recommend their hot chili oil fish fillet
author: Momo P.

description:
My man friend and I stopped in this evening for a bite to eat after work. In all honesty, I had a tummy ache but told myself to buck up and shut up. So we got a bunch of things to share, my favorite thing to do on a date. I think you learn a thing or two about someone by the things they order when ordering for two. Fortunately we both like a lot of the same foods, so it worked out.

We got the Potstickers, Green Onion Pancakes, Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce, and the Princess Chicken. Everything was very tasty: the chicken was super good, spicy, hot, crispy, slightly sweet, green onion pancake was thinner than I usually have it which was a good thing. Potstickers were lightly fried and juicy, and the Chinese Broc was perfectly cooked. 

I gave three stars because this place was not really my scene. It was clean and fine, but I am personally more into the dirty little hole in the wall Chinese places. It felt very Americanized and chain-y, there were tons of white people eating there, never a good sign to me at a Chinese spot in Chinatown. But regardless, I had a pretty nice time chatting, nibbling, and sipping a Sapporo.
author: Crystal C.

description: This place is probably a little too spicy for kids, but if you want to take your chances, you can always order something that is not spicy. I like chop sticks, and the table service starts off with only chop sticks; you can always ask for forks and spoons. Other than that, the food was splendid!!
author: Renee G.

description:
This is a very small, but extremely busy place for authentic Szechuan food. There was a waiting list for people to go in for lunch on a Friday afternoon. They take down your name on a notebook and you wait for them to call you. It was a little frustrating as with all the people waiting in line to get seated, some people were done eating and just hanging out...which...SURE it's their right, but it's kinda annoying. We were seated at the same table as two other people across from us, already eating. It was kinda awkward at first, but hey, everyone just wants to eat. 

We ordered chicken with explosive chili pepper, these pickled cucumber salad, and I think some noodle soup. It was all VERY SPICY, and yet so delicious. Just be aware that they don't joke around when it comes to spicy. In retrospect, I should have ordered a side of rice to help balance out the spiciness. Overall, very good, very packed and busy during peak hours so be prepared to wait, and deal with limited personal space. You can't tell a whole lot from the outside, but it's very nice interior inside, and big portions of food.
author: Lola H.

description: One of my go-to places for amazing, spicy szechuan food.  I haven't tried anything I  haven't liked,  but then again I usually order the same dishes over and over again because they area so good! The spicy noodles are my fav :)
author: Megan H.

description: Very tasty. Note: Large portions so we wasted some food. 3 dishes are fine for 4 people depending on your appetite.
author: Art O.

description: Good, but not actually that spicy. Which is disappointing given their name. I got their mapo tofu at the spiciest level and found it to be tasty but nowhere near the heat level I would expect or am looking for. Their house noodle dish is very good, great for the price and has the proper numbing kick that I am looking for.
author: Kane D.

description:
Good taste，original service（in fact，not good enough）. Good service should include of reminding customers when they       apparently order too much to eat up，or offer half choice，so to avoid food wasting！
When check，no printed bill，we pay cash，forget to pay by credit！
author: Qin Y.

description:
Authentic Sichuan restaurant that showcases hau jiao or the famous Sichuan numbing pepper-- an awesome feat considering that 99% of Szechuan restaurants in the USA lack this vital spice. Dishes we tried were the fish with chili oil, bean jello with chili and dry string beans. Best to go with a bigger group to try more items. Definitely focus on the "folk" menu and steer well clear of the "white folks" Mandarin items. 
My only complaint is this place uses WAY TOO MUCH SALT. Shame on the chefs for that.
author: Brian J.

description:
Went here like many others do after an unsuccessful attempt at Z&Y. Came here and the service is crap, absolute garbage. Had to get up and get their attention to order and pay. And they would never come refill water/tea which sucks when you are eating spicy food. 

The food was pretty decent. There was a spicy cold noodles dish that I really enjoyed and they gave a lot of the Fuqi feipian, but something seemed off there. I feel like they were missing certain meat parts of the dish. I always just a szechuan place by it's shui zhu yu, and this just had an average one. However, they did give a lot of rice...so yay?
author: Victor D.

description: The worst service I have ever experienced. Our server had the manners of a rock I will never eat there again.
author: Alex V.

description: The food was really good but not all that spicy. Had the twice cooked pork and chicken with exploding peppers. Both were really good. The service was good too. If I worked nearby it would definitely be in the lunch rotation.
author: Brian R.

description:
I really wanted to like this restaurant because their menu is actually pretty legit (not much Americanized general tso like dishes) but I had a horrible experience here.   I lived in China for years and speak mandarin so i'm thinking i'm an ok judge.

Si ji dou- So salty that I couldn't even eat it- and this coming from someone who loves salt.  
mushroom dry pot- ok.  Pretty good actually.  
liang fen- disappointing.  The noodle tasted like it had sat around for a long time.
kou shui ji (spit chicken)- Along with the dry pot one of the better dishes.
cold cucumber- so so.

While the food was meh the service was awful.  The waitresses working frequently ignored us and carried a "i hate you and our jobs' expression on their faces the entire night  We sat at a pretty large round table and they didn't even bother to put the rice bowls and dishes in front of where we sat-- forcing us to lean over the table and set them where we get them.   And again- I was speaking to them in Chinese.   

On the plus side- beer is only $4 a bottle.

I will never be going back.
author: Brian P.

description: Amazing food (very spicy if you choose), great people, reasonable prices. Recommend to everyone.
author: Andrew A.

description:
What a treat. Never had the cuisine before. Always you beef and broccoli variety kind of Chinese food. Clients from Schezhuan area brought me here and ordered everything. It was numbing not hot. So you can still enjoy the flavor.   Excellent food. Will be back. 

Ordered big fish. Cukes. Noodles.
author: germaine n.

description:
3.5 stars. First don't make a reservation through Yelp because even if they offer it they don't have the computer to see who has reservations or not. This place is way better than Chong Qing Xiao Mian. The service here is even better and the waitress actually understand a decent amount of English. The place is clean and it wasn't too busy during lunch time. 

I got the tan tan noodles so I can compare it to Chong Qing, and the flavor here is way better, but noodles were too soggy for my liking. 

My coworker said mapo tofu is a must. Even if there's no meat in it you will really like it. Hm.............I ordered it with a side of white rice. It was really good. The flavors and the heat was a perfect balance. I wish there was meat in it though, but I found out I can ask to add it for additional charge. 

The pot stickers came in a cute basket. It was crispy and had good flavor. 

I need to come here with more people to try other things. I think everything on their menu is spicy (that's why it's called Spicy King), but it's not unbearable.
author: Karen H.

description:
forced 15% service charge, didn't even serve water. gave us a super heavy pot and let us serve ourselves


not so authentic either. the sprawn wasn't crispy. instine was difficult to chew. 

i wouldn't recommend this place
author: Evelyn M.

description:
The bf was craving spicy fish soup. We stumbled upon Spicy King and thought we would give it a try.

The apps were pretty good (cucumber salad + five spice beef). 

The mains silky tofu fish fillet soup was a 3 out of 5. My bf's craving was curbed but not the best and not our favorite. The tan tan noodles were very tasty and spicier then the soup.

The service was in the needs improvement category. Ie they served the soup with no spoons or bowls... We had to ask for the rice we ordered... Nothing extra friendly about this spot.

Oh and they charge $0.30 for a to go box!

If you want something decently spice and don't care about service this is perhaps worth a visit otherwise not.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Best Szechuan food in SF Chinatown!
Recommend silky tofu fillet and chongqing xiaomian noodle!
author: Crystal L.

description: Really happy that we have another alternative for good spicy Chinese food other than Z&Y. Really good food but very spicy...just the way we like it. Service is not the best but it's about what we expect of an authentic busy Chinese restaurant.
author: Cindy W.

description: My husband and I wanted to grab a little snack and we both love hot and sour soup so we stopped in Spicy King. By far the BEST hot and sour soup we've ever had!!! We also had Kung Pao chicken that was very good as well! Highly recommend!
author: Lisa O.

description:
this place was really subpar, the food was okay. the chicken with explosive chili's just had way too many chili's. i've been to other places with the same dish where they gave us a reasonable amount, but this place really tried to make the dish look bigger and get away with giving less chicken by going overboard on the chili's. the chicken fried rice was okay, nothing special, kind of bland. tasted like the frozen one you can get at costco to be honest, but it wasn't bad. the eggplant dish was pretty good, again nothing special. the chicken in the chicken dish itself was really good, the chili's just ruined it. the complimentary tea was really good, similar to the same tea they give you at most places, but as a big tea fan i really enjoyed it.
the service deserved zero stars honestly. our waitress tried to walk away every time. she didn't give us the tea until we specifically asked for it, and the food took forever to get there. in addition, these three dogs kept running everywhere and barking really loudly. who knows if they were in the kitchen or something while the food was being made. that was really concerning.
all in all, the taste of the food was okay to somewhat good, but the service was just terrible.
author: Rachel C.

description:
This is a complex review, but here goes. I'm giving this a 4 star but I want to give it 3 1/2. 

Why?

Being an American, I have come to expect my Chinese food to be a certain way. This food may have been to close to what actual Chinese food is like and I have yet to acquire an appreciation for it. I had the spicy chicken. 
    My spicy chicken was SUPER spicy. But what turned me off is that it was dry (no sauce) and for the price did not come with rice or noodles $13.95. Rice was $5.   Now don't get me wrong. It tasted great. I had to order a side of sweet and sour sauce to tone down the spicy flavor.   We also had Mongolian chicken. Also very good flavor $9.95. 

Come before 5pm. This seems to be a popular place. The waitress was swamped with all the tables until the other hep came in. 

Overall it was tasty. Just not what I'm used to eating.
author: Paul H.

description: Stopped by for takeout.  Crowded. Portions are huge. Got garlic eggplant. Enough for two. Well balanced with flavor and spice.  There was a wait, but expected, given that they were full.  Will definitely go again when in town to explore more of the menu.
author: Steven E.

description:
OMGGGGG GUYS THIS PLACE IS THE BOMB

Even if you don't speak Chinese, you could get by since the servers we had that day spoke English really well, but that doesn't make this place less legit. It is DELICIOUS.

You in for some spicy Si Chuan food? Then get, it, girl, and get your stomach ready.

Things we got: ma po tofu, a combination clay pot, garlic eggplant (duh), and black bean spicy beef. Also the noodles. And, at the request of my boyfriend, even though I kept giving him skeptical "are you sure" looks and comments, preserved eggs with jalapenos.

The ma po tofu didn't come with the ground pork that I expected, but it actually worked out well because it means the vegetarian in the room got to eat it. And even without the pork it was full of flavor, and the tofu was that perfect firm but but not too firm.

The combination clay pot was full of red peppers, and was like a little "find your treasure" kind of situation. Spam, beef, shrimp, fish, lotus roots, bamboo shoots, mushrooms--it was all thrown in there, and you just had to dig past the pepper corn and chiles to get your favorite parts. A lazier person would've been over it. I was showing off my chopstick skills and in full Mama Bear mode, so I was into it.

Black bean spicy beef was solid. The noodles were SO GOOD. The chewiness of ramen, and the spicy broth that made me think of Korean ramen.

Even the preserved eggs with jalapeno were good, floating in a spicy chile oil, the creaminess of the preserved egg help cutting into the spiciness.

The one thing that I'll say is that you have to order rice separately, which makes me a little sad face, because I think rice should come with food, but they have hot pot, so it makes sense that it doesn't come with the entrees.

The wait was LONG, but the food was def worth it. I am for sure coming back to eat more.
author: Rosy H.

description:
Oh my gosh the food here was SO good!! Get the dry noodles and eggplant with garlic sauce (best I've ever had) for sure. The whole fish, beef hot pot and bbq squid were also super delightful. The chili chicken was strongly flavored with szechuan peppers, so unless that's your jam, beware. 

We came with a big group on a Sunday night, and some of us (the couples in the group) actually had to share plates because they had run out. I've never had to do that before! But we had a good time. I'd definitely come here again for food with some close friends, but if you're planning to have a nice dinner with some unfamiliar people then I would caution you to go elsewhere.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Solid lunch. Reasonable. Clean, good service and a huge menu.  I only wish I would have had more friends with so we could have tried multiple dishes in one sitting 

Loved the hot and spicy soup and G loved his dish with pork and beef in a spicy broth.  

Will be back again and again.  I want to try all the unique hot items they offer.
author: Samanta V.

description: Delicious fried rice! Menu has LOTS of choices, some for the very adventurous. Relatively quick service, price reasonable.
author: Victoria H.

description: Terrible service, called ahead to order take out. Upon arriving was made to wait half an hour for the dish, and then told no more rice that I ordered ahead. This could have been told to me way earlier and I could go somewhere else.
author: Jimmy L.

description: This is the one of the best spicy Chinese restaurants I've tried in USA so far. We tried House Cold Noodle, which was big enough for two people and it tasted not very spicy and a little bit sweet, but it is delicious. We also had Spicy Kidney and Chong Qi Mao Xue Wang, it's also good (the main tastes of them were numbing and appetizing instead of very spicy) All in all, I am very satisfied with the food. The service was just ok.
author: Xueming G.

description: Every single thing we've eaten here is the best Chinese food we've had in San Francisco. Tan tan noodles are the best noodle soup, better than any ramen noodles you can find. So much flavor. They're portions are big and everything is just great.
author: I S.

description: This would have been a 3-4 Star review if not for the roach... We were in San Fran for a few days in Nov and had dinner here. Menu had a wide selection, food was pretty good, decor was cool, and we had a huge round table in one of the like booth nooks which was also cool. The tea is in these heavy cast iron kettles, also neat. BUT when we were pretty much done eating, I saw a roach fall from the hanging light fixture onto the table. We're all afraid of bugs and were trying not to make a scene while trying to get a waitress's attention and keep an eye on the roach. I think they initially thought we were trying to skip out on the bill or something cuz they couldn't find the roach at first. Anyway, we didn't want to hang around there so we waited for our check towards the front of the restaurant. I think they ended up applying a 15-20% discount which, in hindsight, was probably not enough but we just wanted to get out of there. We tried not to think about what could have been in our food.
author: Irie S.

description:
Get the pork belly! SO. GOOD.

There seems to always be a wait here and the staff is constantly busy/lacking.  But the food is awesome.  I love all the noodles too.  

Pro tip: don't wear white.
author: Joyce C.

description:
THIS PLACE WILL MAKE YOU SICK. NO JOKE.

VERY unclean and the owners/employees seem not to care about it. You can find way better authentic food in chinatown without having to sacrifice your health and money. Please don't waste your time here! Walk around the corner and find 3 or 4 choices that are much better. Enjoy SF!!
author: Jason C.

description:
I went here on Friday for dinner and it was just aweful. We got the chicken, duck soup, pork, and chow mein. Both the pork dish and chow mein were super salty. The chow mein had a ton of soy sauce in it. 

The chicken and duck soup were good. They were really spicy. However, be warn with both of these dishes the food is sitting in a pool of chili oil.  The chili oil is how they make everything spicy. It's so greasy. Yuck. 

They also charge $0.30 for each small to go box. The horrible food plus the costly to go boxes made it easy to waste all that good and leave it behind. Not returning back to this again.
author: Rose Z.

description: It only took one bite (of ANY dish) at Spicy King to make it my new favorite restaurant. No joke! Don't let the spice in the air intimidate you, but rather pull you in as a preview of what's to come. My go to dishes, garlic eggplant, mapo tofu, and the greens! This place is authentic as it gets when it comes to Szechuan food and cannot think of a better place in the area. I recommend this place for any and every occasion. Suitable for everyone, even vegetarians!
author: Talia A.

description: Went to this restaurant for lunch. Even though the food was nothing to brag about ,but the service was good, so decided to go again for dinner tonite. The two waitresses that were serving tonite were the  most unfriendly and rude servers .Would never go back there again. If the tip was not added to the bill, I would have left without tipping them.
author: Sarwat R.

description: ahhhh - not sure if it's because my tastes have changed, but i think the spice has become so much milder than before! crazy. meeps! i want to try some of the other new hunan houses in chinatown..
author: Christina L.

description:
Customer service is so bad!!!
45 min wait last night!! They kept speaking Chinese to me even though I already said so many times I can't understand Chinese! 
I ordered 5 items for 2 people - 4 out of 5 came out to be cold dishes on a night that's already really cold. I asked the waitress if those were good and she just said yes. Can only eat the tan tan noodle - and pack the rest home because they were too cold to eat!!!
I paid $3 for tips because they Never come when we wanted to order more items, and I feel unsatisfied with the food- another waitress came and ask for more tips because $3 wasn't enough?!? She got into an argument with me and keep saying if food is good I should give more tips... wtf
author: Vi K.

description: Spicy King to the rescue!  We had a group of 10 for my friend's birthday lunch and they were able to accommodate us at one big circular table.  And let me tell you, the things they brought to that table were absolutely fantastic.  I had lamb w/ peppers, people loved their Peking Duck, the potstickers were ridiculously good, and the list goes on.  I had been there before and loved it, and so did this whole group.  Definitely a great China Town find
author: Matt V.

description: I've been here about five times and I've only had their noodles. I've had their tan tan noodles, spicy noodles, beef noodle soup, and noodles with eggplant. I'd give them all 5 stars and they are not as spicy as you would think!
author: Jessica Z.

description:
If you like spicy food AND Chinese food then this is the place.

Food was amazing (all of it) and reasonably priced.  Try the spicy eggplant because it's AMAZiNG!!

Service is well........not great but given the ladies barely speak English I can live with it
author: Robert K.

description: Best Asian food experience ever. The beef tendon is delicious as an appetizer and the portions of everything on the menu are huge! Be prepared to eat when you come to this place. This is hands down the best in China Town. If you don't eat here you will be sorry. I tried a few other places in the area and was sadly disappointed. This place delivers!
author: Franklin H.

description: It's a wonderful place for people who like spicy stuff. We got the sour and spicy noodles. It wasn't that good, cuz it's a lil too sour for me. Also, we got 一品水煮鱼. Thts something I'll definitely try again next time. 麻辣牛肉面(spicy beef noodles) was awesome. I like it. That's a place I'll recommend to my friends and family. :)
author: Lucy S.

description:
Five star solid. You won't find this place peddling menus on the corner of Grant Ave luring tourists in for "authentic Chinese cuisine". They obviously don't need to. Do your self a favor and walk slightly up the hill to Waverly Place for some darn good Sichuan cuisine.

As the name suggests, the standard offerings here definitely have a kick and I'm sure that they could punish you more if requested. I was here with my kids and a friend visiting from out of town, so I kept the selections a bit tame but everything we ordered was great and we all left full and happy. I'd love to come back here with someone who would help me explore some more of this huge five page menu.

The spicy sauteed green beans were the group favorite and were every bit as good as I remembered from my travels to Shanghai. The salt and pepper shrimp were unexpectedly good, perfectly cooked, lightly breaded, and a great compliment to the other more spicy entrees. I was jealous of the other tables who were sampling huge noodle bowls, hot pots, and other interesting delicacies. Next time...

I haven't explored much of the cuisine in SF Chinatown, so don't actually know how this compares, but for this kid, it was a hit.
author: Shawn W.

description: Been to this place so many times and it never disappoints me!! Food usually comes pretty fast as well. Definitely recommend.
author: Shirley X.

description: Don't know what to say. The food is delicious and decently priced. The service is 100% crap. My husband and I were here for over 2 hours mostly just sitting and waiting. They also didn't get our order correct.
author: Amberly L.

description:
We pre-yelped this place before going since we knew we were going to be staying in the area. I used to live in Chinatown and I really wish I had known about this place at the time!

It was a Wednesday night and the place was totally crowded. We ended up sharing our table with another couple because we were so hungry and the places smelled so great we didn't want to have to wait any longer. 

We ordered the spring rolls as an appetizer. They came out crispy and fresh. That was a great way to start off the food experience.  

Next came the princess chicken. I don't know what flavors they used but the combination was sweet and spicy and drenched in sauce yet the chicken was still crisp. This was definitely my favorite dish of the night.

After the chicken came out we realized that we had ordered some steamed rice and actually had to ask them to bring it out. I'm guessing they forgot too. That kinda sucked.

Lastly came the orange beef. That was pretty amazing too. It wasn't very tough to eat and came with tiny shavings of orange peel cooked into the sauce. That was a refreshing and delightful touch.

So, I really debated if I was going to give this place 3 or 4 stars. The wait staff was absolutely horrible! They never asked us how the food was. Never asked us if we wanted another beer or if we wanted more water. It was a shame. At the end of our meal we were still being ignored and we had to resort to putting out hands in the air like we were in elementary school just to get them to pay attention to us. This place really deserves 3 stars just based on that but the food was just so damn good!
author: Andy S.

description: First 2times, everything was so tasty. This time, hot and sour soup was so blend and it was simply bad. Egg plant dish was not the same. The chef forgot to put aged egg, but the very unfriendly waitress insisted they are under the green peppers and turned out, there was no aged eggs on the plate. I was disappointed to find out that the food quality is not consistent at this restaurant.
author: Yasuko T.

description:
My wife and I might be anomalous, but we really love the simple Chinese dishes we ate all the time when we met, began dating, and got engaged in China. We were pumped about authentic Chinese food in Chinatown, and happier still when we found the menu here, and felt our suspicions confirmed by the mostly Chinese clientele.
The restaurant is not very large, but they do offer to seat small parties together at larger tables. We took this option, but it meant staring at and smelling the amazing foods our table-mates had ordered before we had even placed an order! We went simple: "fish flavored" egg plant, hand torn spicy cabbage, and spicy broth tofu. When the cabbage finally came out we devoured it almost instantly! It was the exact Sichuan style dish we were craving! Sadly, the subsequent dishes were not as satisfying. The tofu seemed to have cracked black pepper, which we found odd, but the eggplant was inedible due to the skin, which we can only surmise was burned.
The service was also very slow. I think they were under-staffed, but the tables that emptied stayed dirty a long time before anyone from the developing crowd at the door could've seated.
If you're looking for fancier dishes, this place seemed to do the trick for whole fish and hotpot, but for more modest fare I think you'd be better off looking elsewhere.
author: Charles G.

description:
Yum yum! This place had great atmosphere.
There was a bit of a wait, but if you are willing to share a table and make new friends you'll get seated faster. 
The prices are reasonable. I will totally come back and eat here on my next return to San Francisco.
author: Rachael Y.

description:
I was originally attracted by the chongqing noodle but as soon as they brought it up it just looks really unappetizing to me. The spicyness and numbness is not as close as the authentic and the veggie they use doesn't seems to be washed properly. 
I will not come here again...
author: Sanli T.

description:
Without much in the way of tasty Sichuan options in the city, my go to has been Z&Y up until now, because, well, they're not bad, and they're close to work. My friends suggested this place a few weeks ago though, so I figured I'd give it a shot. Coming in right at 7pm, the place was already somewhat packed, but even so, I managed to beat a big rush of customers that came soon after I did.

We ordered a few of the usual Sichuanese appetizers: cucumbers, pork ears, and so on, but we actually decided to hot pot it up as our main that night. All in all, everything was just okay. The appetizers were on par with Z&Y's (though the cucumber dish was not what we expected), and while the hot pot was okay, it had a particular medicinal/herbal aftertaste that I wasn't too fond of.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The restaurant is a little on the smaller side, and it seemed to me like some of the tables were arranged closely enough that they wouldn't be accessible. The ones closest the door don't pose any problems, however.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so no comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
The absolute best Chinese food I have ever eaten. 

You must stop here and experience the food and the people. This place alone made the walk through Chinatown worthwhile.
author: Terry M.

description:
Not a bad place if you are craving Szechuan style food. The restaurant is located in the heart of SF Chinatown. It's a small-medium size restaurant, and I can see this place getting packed easily. Luckily, our party of 3 was seated immediately (probably because we were there on a Monday night). 

I would recommend getting the mapo tofu and the fish fillet boiled in chili oil. I felt the taste of the food was more geared towards an Americanized audience. 

No particular reason why I only ranked it a 3-star... It didn't disappoint, but also did not wow.
author: Sherry C.

description:
Ordered the Tan Tan Noodles and was not disappointed. Great flavor and wonderfully spicy. I would eat here again in a heartbeat. Service was not a problem. 

If you like tasty, hot food, then this is the place.
author: James R.
