description: The Szechuan dish is not authentic at all, it is run and cook by all Cantonese folks . we had spicy lamb, the lamb meet was cheap hot pot slice lamb meat, we also had hot spicy fish tufu, the sauce is quit gluey. This is one of the worse Szechuan food, definitely do not recommend .
author: R Z.

description: Ran into this place after some yelping and their Noodles is really good! Definitely coming back to try the other things on the menu!
author: Anna H.

description: I liked this place so much that I brought my family here. But this time，I am pretty disappointed. They lose their genuinety. Dandan noodle is no way close to what it ought to be. It becomes ramen like noodle in soup. Seriously??? So sad that it turns from a great sichuanese Resturant to an ordinary one.
author: April W.

description: I ate here a couple weeks ago and got the panpan noodles. It was soooooo delicious. I've been looking for restraunts across the United States that serve pan pan noodles and have not found any place. I will have to make a special trip into Chinatown when i am in the area next time to feed my craving. The hot tea was very good also.
author: McKinley M.

description:
Very nice for lunch - great location we got here right when it opened and 20 minutes later people were filling in..... Fantastic hot n sour soup 
Great spring rolls
Beef and onions are yummy
Great San Francisco experience 
Onion pancake - Best I have had in a long time
Service is good
author: Lisa C.

description: stopped in this afternoon and got the Ma Po Tofu. I was really disappointed that it wasnt very spicy at all. The service was efficient and the place was clean.Total was $14.54 for mapo doufu and 1 cup of steamed rice, no drink
author: Just S.

description: Waited for more than one hour ! Definitely understaffed, needed to wait for someone to get our orders, needed to wait to pay. Food here is not as good as we expected, and is over priced for the food and service that we got. Would not recommend others to come here if they crave for spicy food (especially during winter) don't get attracted by their fancy menu and food photos !
author: Chun L.

description: The food was good, probably not as spicy as authentic Sichuanese food, but we liked it. I'd give a better rating but, as many others have already said, the service is horrible. We had to wait in line for 30 minutes, then they made us seat in a round table with other four people that weren't with us for another 20 minutes, then finally (despite refusing our request at first when we saw a couple of people leaving) they gave us a table just for the two of us, where we waited for another 20 minutes until somebody finally showed up to take our order (with a not so friendly attitude). Meanwhile the waitresses were just roaming around the restaurant, gathering dirty plates very slowly and trying to ignore all the customers. It's a shame because the food is good and this place could be much better if only they improved the service.
author: Sonia G.

description:
Delicious szechuan place in SF china town. 

I usually get the spicy fish with tofu - basically it's fish and tofu and some vegetables drowned in chilli oil - along with the cucumber salad to cool things down.
author: A H.

description: Found this place on accident a year ago. Went back again just to find this place. Did not disappoint. Second time here-LOVE. Food is amazing!!!
author: Carma H.

description:
Came here for lunch and ordered the chili boiled beef on the lunch menu.  Complimentary hot and sour soup was pretty good.

Beef was nicely flavors and tender.  Only complaint is that it's very much toned down for the non Sichuan (non s.w Chinese) population, so the food is mild.

They screwed up my order... gave me fish instead of beef which they exchanged but somewhat reluctantly.  Service is subpar so don't expect much on that front.
author: Paul K.

description:
Server told my boyfriend & I to sit at the end of the bar right next to the kitchen door where the workers go in & out, because supposedly there were no "small tables" even though there were plenty of small tables (seat of 4) in the back. 

Then when we were about to sit down, a couple who was sitting at a table just paid & left. So, we asked the server if we can sit at the table instead because the end of the bar was too cramped & if we sat there, we would be blocking the entrance to the kitchen for the workers. The server then said "no the other couple who came in after you is going to sit there". Yes, the couple AFTER US. 

So, my boyfriend & I decided to get up & leave soon after because we are not going to take that kind of crappy service & we'll gladly spend our money elsewhere.
author: Yummy T.

description: Best Sichuan food I had ever had. My Chinese friends tell me its authentic Sichuan. We have been back a couple of times. Can't wait to go again.
author: A. A.

description:
Came on a Friday at 7pm, we beat the rush and didn't have to wait. Like a lot of other reviewers noted, this place is comparable to Z&Y, and I think the service is much better. Plus not as many ppl know about this place yet so not much wait. 

Had the following dishes:

sautéed green beans - a tad too salty for me

Garlic Eggplant - I asked them not to make it sweet and this was a win 

Spicy fried chicken - really tasty, comparable to Z&Y

Shredded pork Hunan style - delicious wish it had more meat tho 

Green onion pancake - thin crispy greasy deliciousness
author: Jenn L.

description: It is one of the most popular Chinese restaurants. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. There are lots of Sichuan dishes. We ordered frog flaming pot and fried lotus. They are all delicious and not that spicy like China. You should go there and have a taste.
author: Nancy S.

description: This is one of my Favorite place for dinner in the city.  Great food, great service and even have karaoke in the vip room upstairs. How can u ask for more?
author: Henry C.

description: A good alternative to the long lines at Z and Y
author: David T.

description: The cold noodle is super good, every time I come here I must order this. And this place is a good place for a big group. If my friends don't have any idea for dinner, I would recommend this place for hanging out.
author: Hung Ying L.

description:
First time at this restaurant for Chinese new years.  I'd say this place is pretty good but a bit pricy with some dishes being almost 20 dollars.  Though everything is red, the food is not as spicy as szechuan food from China.  Flavors are good though.

Caution, combination hotpot had a lot of innards, pigs blood, lotus roots so if you don't like that stuff don't order it!
author: connie h.

description:
Once we walked in nobody seated us and we were trying to find our way. Nonetheless most of the bigger tables were available, they really wanted to sit us (party of two) on the tiniest table in the restaurant. This would be okay, if we didn't have to wait for the previous guests to pay and clear the table. And finally they seated us before cleaning the table. 

The service throughout our dinner was just okay, we had to wait for a while to place our order and get the check at the end. 

In regards of the food: I would call authentic. It's spicy as the name of the restaurant tells. Each dish comes with steamed rice and you need this to extinguish the fire :-)

Be aware that there are nearly no non-spicy dishes. 

Summarizing: an authentic place with a Chinese-efficient service.
author: Martin Z.

description:
We ate at this restaurant for lunch today. There were 5 of us.  The food overall was so-so, with dishes like Tan Tan noodles being a little in the bland side and with little spice at all. 

The service was terrible.  We waited almost 20 minutes before they came and took the drink order and another 5 before they took the food order.  They brought us out 3 orders of rice when we only ordered one, but they charged us for all three.  And they didn't bring the drink order until being reminded twice, and it finally showed up when two of us were already finished with our meals. Then we waited 15 minutes to get the bill and finally gave up and paid at the front. 

It was not an enjoyable meal and the service didn't help so I could not re come d this restaurant.
author: Chris D.

description: Food is too spicy for my palate but the flavors were great.  We ordered the garlic pork belly ( which is served cold, the server let us know which was much appreciated) and the tan tan noodles which was ground pork and veggies noodle soup. Located in the heart of Chinatown.
author: Rose R.

description: Awesome spicy Sichuan food. The duck soup wasn't my favorite but every pork dish was amazing. Wish the Sapporos were 16 oz cans
author: Sean R.

description:
Walking through Chinatown, a few of the people I was traveling with became hungry and wanted some good food. A woman approached us and gave us menus to Spicy King. We were apprehensive at first because most places that do street advertisement like so usually turn out being fast food Chinese that you can find anywhere. When we stepped into the place we were surprised by how nice it was! It's small and sort of cramped, but the decor is beautiful. There is a neat looking tiki bar, a fish pond and other little odds and ends that added to the atmosphere. 

I wasn't very hungry so I just sipped on tea and ordered pot stickers which were very good! Probably the best I've ever had. The other two people I was dining with ordered a sort of deal for two (for I think around $20-25) in which they received soup, two entrees and rice. It was so much food. Everything looked amazing! 

Service was a bit slow, but the servers were very friendly. I guess slower service must be a common thing on the more laid back West Coast - something us East Coasters should learn from.
author: Aj S.

description: Mediocre service, slow and unfriendly. My chicken dish consisted of about 20 pct chicken to 80pct chopped, dried red chiles. Chicken was good, but not much of it. Spring rolls were excellent.
author: Susan R.

description: OMG the 小锅米线 is so amazing!! Definitely the taste of my hometown Yunnan. However the "小锅" is huge though, almost the same size with my face~~ LOL
author: Ruo W.

description:
I've been here twice, but I'm already pretty much in love with this restaurant. I've never been to China, but out of all of the Szechuan places I've been to across the country, this place has got to be one of, if not, the best. Although this place is tucked away in Chinatown, the have a large space that's great for fairly big groups (~7 or 8 people).
Service here is not that great, if you're expecting someone to come in and check on you often or being able to flag down a waitress quickly, but I think it's perfectly fine. The staff here does hit the major points: takes orders well, delivers food fairly fast (even when they're crowded), and brings the check at the end of the meal.
The real winner of this place truly is the food. Service aside, this place deserves 5 stars for the taste of their dishes. I love the explosive chili chicken and mapo tofu. It's such a hearty, comforting meal with a bit of a kick. I'm a huge fan of spicy food, so I don't feel the heat, but if you struggle to consume Tabasco, this place may not be for you.
If you ever find yourself in Chinatown, seriously check this place out!
author: Marissa O.

description: If you order hot expect hot. No refills city water be ready with plan B or survive the heat. I can't fuss about spicy when the menu is clearly marked.  The restaurant does well at balancing spicy with flavor. As long as you accept the warnings you won't be disappointed.
author: David L.

description:
We ordered 3 dishes. The first one changed its presentation and flavor, again. As a Sichuan native, I don't expect authentic food but somewhat closer taste will do. 

The second one was clearly wrong. We ordered a stir fry beef dish. But this one came in a soupy pot. We called our waitress, a shorter Chinese girl. She looked at the menu with the picture, and told us "we don't do the dish in this picture any more". Excuse me? This is called false advertisement. When we asked for the manager, she said "the boss is not here" and walked away. 

In 15 minutes, we checked with that waitress again, not knowing what she was doing with our mixed up order. She repeated her defense "the boss is not here", and walked away again. 

And after that, our 3rd dish never arrived, never......

Needless to say, we won't be back, ever......
author: Jennifer L.

description: Have been here many times with different group of people. Food is simply amazing, however service has always been on the lower side. This place is always busy and seeing two waitresses running around makes you feel sorry for them. They keep on forgetting my order -sometimes drinks sometimes rice- takes them forever. I still love this place n keep on going back. If only they could focus on service!!
author: N B.

description: All was good. Had spicy fish, green beans, intestine, lamb. Everything was flavorful but I think the lamb was likely the highlight of the lunch. Others preferred the intestine, though. You just have to try as much as you can and make your own mind up. Flavors are on point, that is the main thing. If you see something you usually like, try it!
author: Mark K.

description:
We went for lunch. They have huge menus with tacky photos of two chefs on the cover wearing numerous medals (medals from what, who knows) around their necks, and beautiful tasty looking photos of all the dishes. But there is fine print that says something like our dishes may look different from the photos. Ordered a bowl of dan dan noodles and a bowl of chongqing noodles. The chongqing noodles had a tad more of the numbing spiciness, and included a few tiny strips of lettuce-like vegetable. The dan dan noodles came in a different style of bowl, and had a teensy tiny bit of sweetness in the broth, but other than that the two were virtually the same. There were only maybe 3 tiny crumbs of ground meat in the dan dan noodles. Where's the meat?

Just because there's that disclaimer on the menu, it doesn't mean it's okay to leave out one of the three usual components of the dish. The noodles were tasty...but...they were plain noodles and sauce. For $18. Which doesn't sound like a lot, but they were just plain noodles, and that's 30% to 50% more than the average lunches in Chinatown, lunches that include actual ingredients like meat and vegetables.

Service/decor - I would have thought they had only been open a couple months, and were just ironing things out. Didn't realize till looking at Yelp now that they've been open 2 years. Service was totally disorganized. It wasn't that busy and people walked back and forth inefficiently and it wasn't always clear who worked there. The decor is gimmicky. Little bowls have scalloped rims which looks kind of cool, i guess, but there's a reason why no other places use bowls like this. It's not very conducive to the Chinese way of shoveling rice into your mouth, or sipping soup directly from the bow. They sat us at the "bar" which ended up being very uncomfortable. I felt like a toddler without my booster chair because the counter was at bar height but they used regular height chairs there. Eh.
author: Mai-Sie C.

description: The food here is very good. Some of the best Sichuan food I have had in the US. The place was very busy and understaffed. Had to wait about 30 minutes for a table for 2 on a Saturday night. The waitstaff was hustling hard, but there simply wasn't sufficient manpower to serve the tables and clean/bus the empty tables by the 2 or 3 waitstaff. Once seated, the drinks were brought and eventually the food came. The food was very good. Highly recommend this place. Just be patient and you'll be glad you waited.
author: Kbob K.

description: Great place to try. Authentic Chinese food. If you're looking for typical American Chinese food this is not the place but I would suggest you try it. Clean and professional, bathroom is clean and nice. the food comes out hot! It was a quick service, the place seems pretty full but our food was out quickly. Attentiveness is low. Out of water and haven't came back but other than that it's been a great experience.
author: Anna G.

description: Greasy and open late. What more could you ask for!!?? Pretty tasty dishes.  They were fast as hell!  I enjoyed it.  Give 'em a try!
author: Wouldn't You L.

description: The atmosphere is nice, however we did not get the fried rice that was ordered as well as water. The food we did receive was not the greatest either. The food is also far overpriced.
author: Taylor T.

description:
The service is terrible! My girlfriend's jacket doesn't want to eat any food but we found some oil on it when we left! The waitress just did a simple clean up but no apologies, so disappointed with their service. 

Be prepared for a long time for your food after you are seated. 

上菜慢服务差！重庆小面估计是没有煮熟，特别难吃。
author: Fred L.

description:
I lived in Chengdu for 2 years, and since I've been back, I have been looking for authentic Sichuan food. I found it here! It was a great place for me to introduce my favorite Sichuan to dishes to family and friends here in the USA. 

I was so happy to see 凉面，担担面，以及热干面！

我在四川住了两年。自从我寄来美国以后，我一直找地道的川菜。这里我就找到了！为我是一个在美国很好的给家人和朋友介绍一下川菜的饭馆。看到了凉面，担担面，和热干面,我就开心啦！
author: Andrew O.

description: Phenomenal food! Every single dish was far above average, including some of the best I've ever tried. Language barrier was an issue, but well worth it for the quality
author: Brennan R.

description: Truly awful. Waited an hour in the restaurant for my take-away order. Saw plenty of people walk in after us and get their meals while we continued waiting. Unfortunately paid and tipped at the start, otherwise I would have simply walked away. We asked for our money back after 40 minutes but was told it was almost ready then waited another 20 minutes. Their excuse was that there was only one chef working that day, but clearly they were prioritising other people. After an hour, the food was greasy. Could not recommend less. Worst experience we had in San Francisco.
author: Alic J.

description:
food : 3 stars. We ordered boiling fish and pot chicken. Even i have ask for less salty, the chicken is still very very salty.


Service: 1 stars. We are Asian. we requested ice water. But  the waitress brought was temperature water. No ice. No lemon. The customers next to us are white people. The servicer brought them ice water with lemon.
The store was lack of servicer. There were only two waitresses. Therefore, the service was very slow. 
Also, we waited for one hour to get our two dishes ready. 
When the waiter brought the tea, the hot water was sprayed to my leg! He was not intentional. But he was not professional at all. He filled the tea pot too full.
author: Fangfang O.

description: I should say something after visiting there with high expectation. I ordered the guilin rice noodle which is my hometown popular food. I want to say this food is not good. If you come here,  it had better not order this food.
author: Lizi X.

description:
I dislike giving places a 1 star review, please but hear me out.

My girlfriend and I was in the mood for exploring Chinatown. We always go to ABC Cafe or Washington Cafe. A stroll down Waverly Place was our route of exploration. Either of us have eaten here, so what the heck, lets go out of our comfort zone. 

The menu on windows looked enticing. As we walked in, there was a lady with a clipboard asking us to put our name down. The joint was packed and full of patrons. It looked clean and well maintained (I don't know if it is due new ownership or has alway been like this.) After waiting 20 minutes (and looking through the menu with very small type) or so, the two party of two people ahead of us was seated. They were seat next to each other in a rather small joint tables. 

There were 2 girls behind us and we let them go ahead of us because we wanted to be seated at a table for 2 (not sharing a small table with other patrons.) They sat at a  big round table to be shared with other patrons. After another 15 minutes, their table was not yet cleared or any attention given to them.

We waited patiently and saw a table of 2 leaving so we can have their's. This is when my patience started to wane. The lady with the clipboard is also a street hustler who is on the street passing out menus to tourist and people walking by.

She obviously did not care about us because she serviced a party of 9 people to sit before talking to us. That is when we said enough and walked out.

Inclusion, we waited almost 50 minutes (willing to share a reasonably sized table with other patrons.) None of the employees seemed to care about service. The two waitresses looked extremely unhappy while working. 

We walked down the street to Utopia Cafe.
author: Tony N.

description: Spicy King is one of the best Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area! Their food are not only taste great, but also look awesome!!! Check it out and you won't be disappointed.
author: Gary T.

description: Just had the sesame chicken with rice but even that was delicious and exceptionally cooked! Enjoyed people watching and talking to a few locals who thought the restaurant was very authentic. Great dinner experience in Chinatown.
author: Ashlie L.

description: Had the mandarin dinner for 2.   Very tasty included spring roll, hot and sour spicy soup.  Mongolian beef and cashew chicken.  All very good. Definitely would recommend.
author: Elena M.

description: Better than many mainland China restaurant. A little bit expensive but worth the price.
author: Yin S.

description: I was surprised by how authentic the flavors were here. We came on a rainy day so fortunately there was no wait. My friend and I shared the enoki mushroom salad, she had the gong bao chicken and I had the eggplant in garlic sauce. All the flavors were delicious and authentic. Run, don't walk to try the eggplant, seriously.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
Some of the dishes here are okay while some are just awful.  For being spicy king we didn't find their spicy menu to be remotely hot.  Some of the menu tasted prett bland.

For being in chinatown I think you can find way better food.
To their benefit their service was prompt and the decor inside was really nice.
However, I judge a place by the food, not by the service or decor and the food doesn't cut it here especially when there are plenty of better places just a few steps away.
author: Daryl D.

description: We were wandering around Chinatown during the parade and found this place. Bottom line: The food was good, the service was terrible. Had to search for the waiter to order (we were in a cubby) and ordered a simple dinner for two. Asked for water, the waiter brought us a carafe with NO glasses. Flagged him down and asked for glasses, he said they only had paper cups (?) then he brought glasses. After 45 minutes with no service (we were talking) searched for the waiter again.... Apparently he had FORGOTTEN to place our order. Had to get the manager to get the order placed. Thought they might comp us or give us something extra for this snafu, but nothing (even charged for the takeout boxes). It was early in the evening and not yet full so there were no excuses for this bad service. I hesitated to make this review, but apparently poor service is standard here.
author: Josie E.

description:
This is an authentic Chinese restaurant.  Since it was highly rated we stopped in.  First thing to note is that if you're looking for this place, there's no sign for "Spicy King" outside it.  I think it was like Uncle something...

Anyway... I ordered their lamb dish and and I can't remember what my husband ordered.  We're Caucasian and have never eaten at an authentic Chinese restaurant so we probably should have gone with something familiar like beef and broccoli.  (Yes we've had chinese-american food a million times, but definitely different from the real deal, which is why we stopped here...)  Anyway, the waitress made a big deal of telling us the food was spicy, specially my husband dish because its had "spicy" in the title.  Both dishes were fine.  My husband and I actually traded our dishes because we each liked each other's better.  I didn't think either dishes were "spicy" at all.  I know some white people can't hold even a dash a pepper, but that's really the only spice they added to our dishes.  Not sure if they toned it down for us even though we said we were fine with spice... oh well..

The pot stickers were amazing.  And I really liked that they served tea instead of water here, but our main dishes were just kinda barely tolerable.  They just didn't taste that good.  Oh well...
author: Cassandra A.

description: My friend and I had finished eating our meal and we were figuring out the bill. I saw something out of the corner of my eye and I remember thinking "is that what I think is is?" It was. A RAT ran under my friend's chair and then ran back out again. I instantly jumped out of my chair and out the door. That was the first time I've ever seen a rat inside a restaurant - it totally turned my stomach and freaked me out. I will NEVER be going back.
author: Joanna L.

description: This was a great, local restaurant off the beaten path.  My wife and I were looking for a good Chinese restaurant for lunch and was handed a menu at one of the street corners on Geary Ave.  We looked at it, reviewed yelp and decided to take the risk.  The lady passing out the menus walked us one block to the inside of the restaurant, which was very impressive.  The place was very busy... We were immediately greeted, seated, provided menus and tea/water was already coming.  We ordered traditional items; Spring Rolls, Kung Pao Chicken, Mongolian Beef, Steamed Rice.... And, was given the opportunity to increase or decrease the spicy.  The food was delicious!!!  Very authentic!!!  Amazing!!!  Definitely would go back again.  We had a choice to sit with another couple (mom/daughter), which happened to be locals.  They order 3 dishes, and said it was the best place around.
author: J. E.

description: If you love Spicy Foods, this is the place. Everything has chilis in it. The only thing is, the wait time can be long. Most people who had dinner here, very relaxing and enjoying their time, so the wait for the table could be long. And this place is not that big.
author: Maria S.

description: When I lived closer to this placed I used to go all the time. Food is food and see if was pretty good too. For some reason now I don't like spicy food so I don't go to places like this as often. My boyfriend loves spicy food so we come here from time to time. He always orders the lamb and I like the tofu stuff they have but always ask for it to be less spicy. It's a good place to come with the family. I will be back again
author: Peishan H.

description:
The restaurant was clean and the food was good but the waiter was really rude. 

There was only 3 of us and they automatically charged us tip. They didn't even deserve the more than 20% tip that they put down. But we went ahead and paid it anyways. We paid in cash and just let them keep the change; however, as we got up to leave they rudely stopped us and told us we haven't paid any tip. To which, we had to point out that they had already charged us on our bill.
author: Matt H.

description: I spent a month in Chengdu and let me tell you this is the closest to the spicyness I experienced over there. The fish in hot oil was great, the eggplant was flavorful and the numbing tendon was a delight. It was a little on the expensive side for one person but it was a treat since I'm the only one in the family that likes it hot!!
author: Tony A.

description: Not much good to say here. Spicy pork was decent. Crazy hot chicken was crazy hot....good but way too many chiles. Mixed vegetables were DOA drowned in a SWEET sauce. Service okay. Would not return.
author: Cliff C.

description: I'm searching for a restaurant serve spicy food for a long time. This is definitely a good place for ppl crazy about spicy food. However, I hope the food can be more spicy. The price is good too.
author: Sicong Z.

description: The sweet and sour soup with pork intestines looks amazing. The taste and portion was all there. Yet, the color and water volume was not quite right. I'm used to more of a thicker brown sugar water-base than the separated, clear liquid. Maybe it can use a little less bean sprouts too. I feel like it tries to be pho and soup at the same time. You definitely get both in volume, but I would use less water and emphasize the clear golden noodles.
author: Edward G.

description:
I'm a big fan of spicy Chinese food and this is the best one I've been to so far in comparison to Z & Y and Hunan (I've only been to 3 spicy Chinese restaurants in San Francisco so far). I may be an outlier though since I ate really really spicy food ever since I was a child. 

I don't remeber the english name of the dishes right now. I ordered 辣子鸡 (spicy chicken), 水煮鱼 (spicy boiled fish), and this other spicy beef dish that  had a fancy decorative wooden cage-like thing. All of the dishes were really good except slightly too oily but I guess that's kinda expected in these type of dishes.
author: XiaoChuan Y.

description: This one is a good sit and wait restaurant. As we sat down eyes roll in and out. Wait to order but body sway pass left to right....30min went by.. no sign of any communications between the server... so we bail out. it seem that they only focus on Chinese customers. .. they exchange more words than to us.
author: Taijii T.

description: Poor service. Really bad and rude attitude. Only two or three waiters. NOBODY HELPS US ORDER. I'll never recommend this place. BAD EXPERIENCE IN SF.
author: Haocheng H.

description: Took the recommendation from the guy who gave me a foot message. I'm definitely not an expert on truly real Chinese food but he is and I really liked the spicy beef noodle soup. I did whimp out and got it only a little spicy and was very glad I did, as my taste buds are only a little fried and I didn't have sweat running off the top of my head. I will definitely come back the next time I'm in town. Another review mentioned it being hard to get a table and that is probably true, I was by myself and got a single seat at the counter right away. The place was packed at 8 pm on Saturday night, just after the big Chinese new year parade in Chinatown, most of the customers seemed local.
author: Howard C.

description: Second time I've been here and the food is top notch. My mouth is on fire but I've got a smile on my face. If they have pig ear in definitely get it! But everything on the menu from the mundane to the exotic is absolutely delicious. The staff are great and the kitchen is FAST! Get there early to beat the crowd and don't steal the motorcycle in the lobby.
author: Jason D.

description:
I came here with a group of 5. As first timers, unanimously, we all hated it. We ordered 6 dishes, and every single one of them was extremely salty and oily. I could pour out a bowl of oil from the sauce of these dishes (we literally poured out the oil). I generally like food with flavor, but the food here was so salty, it was basically pouring msg down your throat. On top of that, I generally don't have high expectations for tea at restaurants, but the tea served here was basically water. We were curious so we looked into the tea kettle. To my surprise, there was a teabag, but the tea was tasteless? It makes me wonder if they reuse the teabags over and over again.  

We weren't impressed with the service either. We came in with a group of 5, and they decided to seat us at a big table meant for a party of 10. In the middle of our meal, they asked us to move because a group of 14 was coming in. Why seat us there in the first place? 

Also, it is pricey. Every dish is $10+. We (and our wallets) would be way happier going around the corner for better, cheaper Chinese food at Capital. Not coming back.
author: Darlene C.

description:
I got to try this joint on my recent visit to SF and I absolutely loved the food here. I came here with my party of six on a Thursday night and we were seated in 5 mins. 

Two of us ordered the vegetarian dinner option and the rest of the party ordered a shareable pot of the hot and sour soup, prawns flaming pot, sauteed string beans, onion pancake, spicy beef noodles, and rice. 

The noodles were flavorful, spicy, and not at all overcooked accompanied with onion, broccoli, & carrot. The onion pancake was savory and not soggy as I'm used to from other restaurants. The string beans were absolutely delicious here! They had the right amount of bite, sauce, saltiness, and spiciness. The spring rolls that came as part of the veggie option were average, yet good. The hot and sour soup was super yummy and definitely hit the spot as it was quite chilly that night! It was both spicy and tart. The rest of my party enjoyed their spicy beef noodles saying it was a good combination of salty and spicy. The food was so satisfying, we were all done eating after a few bites.

We were somewhat disappointed with the service here since no one bothered to check up on us for drinks. We had to keep waiving for staff to take notice of us even though we were seated at the biggest table front and center of the restaurant. It wasn't even a busy night. On top of that, we never received the steamed rice we had ordered at the beginning. The waitress later admitted she had forgot & included it in our leftover boxes. Though the service lacked, I can't wait to come back again in the future to try some of their other spicy options!
author: Ana V.

description: Amazing if you like spicy food...Mongolian beef is great.  Service isn't going to blow you away but that is on par with most Asian restaurants.
author: Steven S.

description: Came to Chinatown looking for authentic food and wow this place Hit the spot. Their dishes were all unlike most traditional Asian dishes, they added a spicy flair to every item. We ordered fire chicken and house rice and chow mein plus a three variety suateed vegetables with eggplant, asparagus, string bean and onion that was delicious and I'm not much of a veggie eater. Service was great as well. I would definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: J L.

description: This place serves authentic Sichuan food. Everything was tasty and portion is the right size. They have spicy hot pot, seafood, Chinese skewer and much more.. It used to be a smaller restaurant, now they have expanded with new renovation! Will definitely come again.
author: Nicole W.

description: Bad service attitude...... Ignore us while serving guests who came after us. Choose other Chuan Restaurant in China town.
author: Chaoyi Z.

description: Fantastic. Spicy and delicious.  I will definitely come back when I am in Chinatown.  Highly recommended!
author: claudia g.

description: Guys!  This is the real deal! I have been to China many times, specifically the sichuan province, and this is the most real Chinese food in America I have found! I got the beef noodles (niu rou mian 牛肉面）很好！they also have a great atmosphere and phenomena service! EAT HERE!
author: Brandon S.

description:
Nasty oil (The oil had an overly strong taste), bland, salty, and down right sucked. The worst part was that I was dying of thirst after my first glass of water and had to wait 15 minutes for the server to even notice me. If I was at any other Schezuan Restaurant, I would be more than likely to give that restaurant a better review. I love this food but...

 they gon' fucked it up.
author: Raymond Y.

description:
This is probably one of the better Sichuan food in the area. It's a bit on the pricey side, but it has a nice interior and decent service. Most of the dishes are well made. Last time I was here I had the:

Spicy beef in hot chili oil - beef was tender and there wasn't much vegetable filling. Good dish.
Couple's delight (fuqi feipian) - the flavor was good but they mixed it with beansprout? Wtf?

Another minor disappointment was the lack of spicy wontons (hong you chao shou).

Solid restaurant overall.
author: Jake L.

description:
Spicy King is a decent Szechuan spot in Chinatown.  It's nothing too special - frankly their menu is identical to Szechuan Cuisine Uncle Cafe http://www.yelp.com/biz/szechuan-cuisine-uncle-cafe-san-francisco-2 .


It's a good choice for a weekday lunch when you've got a bit of extra time.  The service is none too quick but the hot peppers won't let you down.  Explosive chicken and noodle soups seem to be the highlight of the menu.
author: Ivan L.

description:
A great new place from the people behind the pot sticker. Hot and spicy Szechwan food cooked authentically and masterfully. 

The preserved egg and jalapeño starter just turned me on to preserved eggs; I'd been cautious, but I'll eat anything that comes out of this kitchen, and I was not disappointed; I'm now going to be eating all the preserved eggs until I can find one prepared as well as this was; probably wont happen anytime soon, as their bitter melon dish has yet to be beaten.
author: John X.

description: Amazing Szechuan food. Authentic and delicious.  Service was lousy but just be prepared for that. The food totally overrules everything else!!!
author: Michael K.

description: Pretty authentic sichuan food.  The 辣子鸡 is especially good.  Service is not great but this is the type of place that you come for the food and not the service.
author: Justin W.

description: My sister took us to this place located in Chinatown. Her friend recommended this restaurant.  Their menu had so many items, and more spicy items than non spicy items. Now being a Korean, I love spicy food, and can handle spicy food. So when the menu said it's spicy, I wondered how spicy it will be. we ordered string beans - a little salty but well seasoned and tasty. Spicy fish and tofu were pretty excellent. Also potstickers were awesome. Not deep fried, it melted in the mouth. Mongolian beef - this wasn't my favorite but the reason is that I am so used to Korean barbecue. This restaurant indeed have authentic Szecheun Cuisine !!!!  I was impressed and pleased !!!  Good pricing.
author: Sean Y.

description: There are delicious cuisine and great service here.I like the environment especially.
author: Cyrus K.

description: We ordered tofu, garlic ribs, and steamed rice.  Neither dish was spicy at all, though advertised as spicy.  The ribs were bone and fat.  The only thing that wasn't disappointing was the steamed rice and water.  At least they got that right.
author: Jerry G.

description:
This is the place to go if you want to have real spicy Chinese food. I came here once a month while I have a facial appointment.
I had tried the following dishes: beef pancake, spicy beef tenders, fire blamed kidney, spicy chicken with chili.....all very good.
Worth a try if you like the real spicy food.
author: Karen S.

description: We came here for a late lunch before the Chinese Newyear parade last weekend.  FYI, this use to be the old Pot Sticker down the street; I was so anxious to try when looking at the old menu at The Pot Sticker at the time & how the two women who own this, were from Z&Y Restaurant (see my review.)  I was not disappointed.  Thjey have a nice small waiting area & music going which goes back & forth from Kenny G to Chinese music.  The service is very friendly & the food top notch.  I started with the pancake with beef; a a thin chewy but not overly so pancake with perfectly seasoned beef wrapped in the form o9f little rolls.  The tan tan noodles are some of the best with well seasoned cabbage & ground pork in a wonderful chili sauce with a subtle one two kick.  The lamb skewers are perfectly marinaded in a robust blend of spices & tender; no sauce needed.  Round it all off with a Ching Dao & you will not be disappointed.  So, for exccellent Szechwan cuisine at reasonable prices in a clean friendly atmosphere, Spicy King cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description: Authentic Sichuan food, very spicy if you are not used to Sichuan cuisine, I would recommend if you fancy something hot!
author: Jericho S.

description: AWESOME FOOD!!! GLAD WE FOUND THE PLACE!! Workers are a little rough and hard to stop (hence the lost star) but really the food is worth it!!!
author: Erica H.

description: I was there with a friend last night. The food was great for sure. But towards the end, I saw a big fat rat climbing down the tree decoration thing. I was terrified. We left soon after. We were sitting at the inner corner of the restaurant. Advice to the management. Do a rat inspection ASAP. It still gives me chills now.
author: Emma L.

description: I'm  not a spicy person however the milder foods were great! I loved the octopus which brought be home, Thank you! waitress were very good and kind, love this place, very clean.
author: George K.

description: By far one of my top ten restaurant's in San Francisco.  The flavor is. This place is so authentic than i swear halfway through my meal im speaking a littlw mandarin. The tan tan noodles hits the spot. Love how almost every dish has plenty of flavor and spices. I eat here at least once a month.
author: Kenneth S.

description:
I was dissapointed.  I ordered a well known spicy Sichuan lamb dish, but I was served something else which the staff insisted was what I ordered.  I will not be going back.

Apparently they were out of the proper ingredients that night, because what I got had lamb, but that was about the only similarity to what I ordered. It was not spicy, it did not contain cilantro, flower pepper or chilis, and the lamb appeared to be extra thin sliced hot pot meat, instead of the usual good stuff.  It was some dish made of stir fried leeks, bell peppers and Lau Gan Ma sauce. 

It was OK, I ate it, but it was not what I ordered.  It would be one thing if they came out and told me that "we are out of some ingredients, but I would be happy to make something else with lamb for you". Instead, when I complained, the staff insisted  was what I ordered. The menu had a picture showing what it should have been! I have ordered this in several other restaurants, and it wasn't even close.  

This is just disrespectful to their clientele. Apparently we can't tell the difference, so it doesn't matter what they fry up.  

Not cool.
author: Ben J.

description:
First things first: 
THEY ACCEPT CREDIT/DEBIT!
We were trying to find a place that was not cash only and this worked out. It was a nice calm interior and the employees were friendly.
It would be really interesting to try a "Master Chef" dish at some point. One dish had a bird made out of food. 
The food was tasty and they have some pretty fun looking options, intestines anyone?
We stuck with the familiar Chinese-American dishes: Curry Chicken, Sesame Chicken, Orange Beef, and Pot Stickers. 

There is debate about which menu item was best - which is a great sign.

Personal Favorite: Sesame Chicken.

Pro Tip: The little water fountain display has live fish in it. It's shallow enough that you can touch the fish. kind of fun. something to do AFTER eating. 

Pro Tip2: The dishes are larger than one person can eat, plan on sharing.
author: Ronnie L.

description: Easily the best sichuan food in SF.  Decent service as well!
author: Mason W.

description: We were sort of "escorted" by a lady on the street to this place and we don't usually do this but we went ahead and had lunch there.  This is an authentic Chinese restaurant. They serve a lot of things western folks don't usually eat.  I have to say that their food is delicious. We ordered things we recognized and the entire place was full. We had to share a large table with two other groups.  We were the only non-Asians here.  That says that they have good fresh food.  We were very glad we came. The service is strained because the place is small, jammed, and a little understaffed for the lunch crowd. However, everyone was kind and very helpful.  I would go there again and I hope with an Asian friend so I can try different dishes next time.
author: April E.

description: This is the worst service I've gotten in a long time. It took 40 minutes to get food when the place was half empty. People who sat down after us got served first. I'll never go back.
author: Jade J.

description: Amazing sauces and flavor! The best Szechuan food I have found in San Francisco. The meat is pretty tough and the service is pretty bad but the food more the makes up for it in my book. Try the brown beech mushroom hot pot, Spicy Numbing beef tendons and sautéed sliced lamb w/pepper!
author: Amy Y.

description: Very yummy food, once you start eating the spicy beef tendon it's hard to stop. They also validate parking, which is great in chinatown. Bring more people so you can try more plates!
author: Alex C.

description: Had Pot Stickers & Garlic Spare Ribs no spicy and Ramen Soup. Potstickers were delicious, ribs were delicious too, the soup was ok. Would try it again.
author: Cindy I.

description: The place looked packed but unfortunately their service is horrible. There was no waiter who even wanted to talk to tell us to wait. It was a bad experience since we waited for almost 15 min before we left because no one wanted to talk to us.
author: Kiran V.

description:
Amazing!! Food was delicious, atmosphere was nice & relaxing, people were friendly. The food is the perfect mix between authentic Chinese food and say, panda country. Some very unique dishes along with  widely known ones. 

Slightly pricey but the portions were huge so plan for leftovers! 

The name of the restaurant is completely accurate, it is spicy! So be careful if you can't handle it.    

Highly recommend!
author: Amber C.

description: This place was great! The best customer service. started with a lady out on the street passing out flyers for this restaurant. she walked us to the restaurant and seated us! She was SO nice! The waitress was real nice to. Food came pretty quick. We had the house fried rice. It had nice chuncks of big shrimp, pork and beef. That was delicious. And we had the spicy beef soup! Which was AMAZING! LOVED IT! I love spicy food and soup so I was in heaven! Highly recommend this place when you visit China Town!
author: Julie R.

description: Best tasting Sichuan restaurant I had in SF so far. Most of the Chinese restaurant in Chinatown are pretty underwhelming compare to ones in Richmond and Outer Sunset. This one is a a hidden gem in Chinatown if spicy meats are your thing. The the interior in the bar area is nicely done too.  Try the beef dish in a basket. (Pictured, Don't remember the name). It's very tender.
author: Charles Z.

description: These guys rock! They made everything extra spicy for us on request. Loved the lamb, string beans, beef kimchi fried rice & spicy dumplings. Will definitely be back!
author: Knee High S.

description: The place used to be great but think the quality of their food came down a lot now. My friends and I used to order hotpot as well as various dishes here, but after trying three times this year, we decided to not come back :/
author: Mei T.

description: Okay, trying this place out because my wife wanted something spicy.  To keep it short and simple, we had the soup noodles.  Mine was a clear broth with not that much spice, but it was supposed to be spicy.  My wife's soup noodle was the numbing kind where it's spicy but it numbs your taste buds.  We also ordered the lamb skewer.  All in all, pretty tasty, but I'm only giving 3 stars instead of 4 or 5 because service could've been better.  They need to either have one more person on the restaurant floor to see if anyone needs anything.  We had to ask for tea!  But I wouldn't mind coming here again; hopefully the service will be better next time, but it's Chinatown so can't expect that much...
author: Philip L.

description: If you like spicy and don't care about terrible service, this is your place. If I didn't come here with friends that are from SF, I would have never discovered my new favorite dish - fish in chili oil. Don't be alarmed by the sheer number of chilies in all of the dishes but don't be an idiot and eat the chili. Lots of dishes for the adventurous foodies.
author: Michelle N.

description: Five stars for for the quality of food and efficiency of service. Our server was sweet, polite, and attentive despite the chaos of being full on Christmas day. There was a line inside and outside. Well worth the wait. For a group of 3 we ordered the Szechuan Dinner. Fantastic!
author: Benjamin T.

description: For serious Chinese Spicy food lovers, I just want to say this is the must-go place. Every dish is very delicious. super super good. I'm a native Chinese and I approved this message... Just one thing need to mention: Chef, you really need hire more waitress. Two waitress to serve over 10 tables is just impossible. There is no service but just endless waiting.
author: Michael C.

description: Wow, words cannot describe my experience with the food here. We ordered beef tripe and some other beef dish to go with that.The service was good, attentive but not annoying. 10/10 would go again.
author: Quan N.

description: I love Szechuan food. Service is not perfect because they need more servers... but food itself is really good. It's not as spicy as other Szechuan restaurants so it'll be good for people who can't eat spicy food.
author: S L.

description: Waitresses here know nothing about customer service and they are boarderline rude to customers. Will be back when im back in town starving and they are the only place open.
author: JESSIE Y.

description: I loved the warm welcome I got when I entered this restaurant.  It was my first time here and I will definetly be back.  My chicken was very spicy but some people say i am a lightweight when it comes to spice.  I like spicy food but i have my limit.  This hit the mark just right.  The waitress was pleasant and helpful.  Parking was difficult but i cant ding the restaurant for that.
author: Juan N.

description:
I was super super super sad to be treated like piece of shit just because am a Chinese and also the waitress is Chinese too. I've been using Yelp for 2 years and this is the first time I sign up because every almost 5-star place I went to was pretty good and this one disappointed me. Am actually born in Sichuan and grow up in there, my family come to visit me. And after few days they got tired of "American food" so I brought them to this place cuz it had almost 5-starts. But when my family was trying to order , somehow the waitress act like she dose not speak Chinese. So I spoke English to her , then somehow she stared to spoke Chinese to me.. I got little bit upset but I was very friendly until she said:"can u guys hurry up cuz I gotta go to eat my lunch."  
We ordered lots food and the table was full, so when she came back with more food, she was just holding the plate until I moved the plate on the table , basically doing her job for her. 
She never came to ask if the food was ok or anything. When I ask her to pack the left over, she gives me a "you such a cheap ass" look that made me kinda angry. 
So far we been treated like nothing so we only paid her $5 for the tips. But she stopped us and said " sorry u didn't paid the tips." I said I didn't like ur service so I didn't  like to paid the tips. And she laugh out loud and said " this is America " ( she looked at my uncle who spoke Chinese to her the first ) " you gotta paid 20% tips , it's the rule." I was mad and about to started a fight or something, my eye was tearing and My face was blushed. But my uncle stopped me and paid the tips to her.
I came to America because I thought here's a free country but I didn't even have right to decide how much I want to pay the tips. This is ridiculous.
author: Xiaopu Z.

description: just want to say-they put the used rice back to the kitchen and then serve it to the next customer. Ok, the spicy chicken took one hojr to cook, cant reture and say we must to pay. I am ok to pay if they have better service. I am done eatting there, no more. And i never recomment the other people to there any more.
author: Xiaojun H.

description: Ordered beef rib and orange chicken. The line is pretty long (30min wait time), but worth the food quality. I liked orange chicken better than the rib. Interior design is beautiful.
author: Mj T.

description: We were waiting quite a while before seated. The service was rude. People who walked in signed in ad we did and they were seated before us. I think this might be friends or family business. The food was very salty. Might I add very poor service. The waitress  took my girlfriend's little boys plate while he was still eating.
author: Steve T.

description: Awesome restaurant and delicious food!!  Please take down the paper placemat taped to the wall that says "no liquor". TACKY TACKY.
author: Gary S.

description:
Was introduced to this place by a colleague (who spent his entire life in Chinatown and rated this as one of his favorites).

Just back from there and had duck chin, pig feet and a couple of other dishes, loved them. (Obviously not a place for anyone expecting standard, Americanized Chinese food).

(The people given this place a 1-star ordered dishes like Mongolian Beef or Peking Duck or Chow Mein... why bother to order these in a Sichuanese restaurant?... also, 
why does the restaurant offer it in the first place?)

Been here about half a dozen times, tried most of the dishes and loved everything.

I found the service excellent, probably because I've been there late in the evening when it was not too crowded.

Decor better than the average Chinese restaurant.

A bit pricey but not way overboard.

Given that almost all the Chinese restaurants in Chinatown are Cantonese this is a welcome change.

Two negatives about the restaurant:

1) Its name; it used to be known as Uncle's Cafe and now has some incomprehensible sign in front (in Chinese). The Spicy King logo in English is to the side (and typically missed)

2) Service. Sucks in terms of getting seated (complete chaos).

3) A ridiculous-looking motorbike occupies a good portion of the restaurant... WHY????

Despite the negatives, I still give it a 5-star (after about probably 20 visits)
author: T S.

description: best szechuan place in town! the ma po is the absolute BEST. and when you order something spicy, they actually make it spicy! what a concept. i am ALL about burning a hole in my stomach.  of course they do mild too. ;)  it's cozy, reasonably priced, staff's super nice, and the food is always delicious. they often have lines, but that's because it's popular and ridiculously GOOD.
author: Kit U.

description: Really Szechwan cuisine! Very hot but very delicious! I must try many more times!
author: Nan S.

description: This is the same restaurant as spicy king.  Restaurant is extremely dirty. Floor seems like it hasn't been vacuumed in months. Staff doesn't speak english. They are friendly but its hard to ask them questions about the entrees. My friend went to the bathroom after the chef came out. He left it uncleaned. I doubt he even washed his hands. If my friend had told me about this before the food came. I would have just left but he told me after we came out of the restaurant. Btw this is the same restaurant as schezuan uncle restaurant. Waiters also seemed biased as if you were asian you would get hot water or tea kettle. But if you are any other you get a lemon water. I would have preferred if they asked me what i wanted. Anyway for the food i would give it one star. For being an authentic Chinese restaurant they definitely need to add more flavor to their food. I have had Chinese and it tastes much better then what these guys offer.
author: Jake L.

description:
It was so good!!! Try the Lemon chicken. Crunchy and delicious. 

Great atmosphere. Clean and waiters are well aware of how you are doing. Will bring the whole family back.
author: cindy t.

description: Stumbled upon this place, and decided to give it a try.  The wait was extremely long, about an hour and a half... there isn't really a place to wait. Food was good.  I didn't like the texture of the beef they use, but the food was pretty good.  My favorite was the Beef & Broccoli.  Great Flavor!
author: Jack M.

description:
Saw this place while walking around Chinatown. Decided to try it out since I am a fan of Sichuan. I tried the FuQiFeiPian (Beef/stomach slices in spicy oil) as appetizer, a ShuiZhuYu (Fish in hot oil), Noodles in with peas and chilli oil paste, Kidney with pickled chilli and tan tan noodle. I looked around and saw another table having an authentic style whole fish in boiling chilli oil sauce. My main regret is not being able to sample all the dishes in one sitting.
My orders tasted fabulous, the fish had the right amount of peppercorn and dried chilli in hot oil, there's no such thing as too much in authentic Sichuan dishes.. The only missing item is fresh sichuan peppercorn but it's banned in California so I can't ding them for this. The timing of servings is bad. They served two items and promptly forgot about the rest for 30 minutes. Come on, this is a casual Chinese restaurant, the proper way to serve is to have every dishes on the table 15 minutes or less after the order. One star off for that. Otherwise, finally, I don't have to deal with anymore Canton-ized Sichuan food in Chinatown! Props for waitresses who are fluent in English, Mandarin and Cantonese! We tried to confuse her by speaking all three together and she handled all without any pauses!
author: Vocal T.

description: Ok Chinese food. I ordered spicy fish filet, the flavor was good but man there was too much salt. After meal I have to drink about 2L of water. The BBQ Lamb skewer was perfect. I also ordered garlic pea sprouts it was salty. Also the waitresses had us sit with strangers then suddenly right before we started eating moved us to sit with another stranger without explanation.
author: Lucky L.

description: Food was good. The service was great! We tried to go to a few other places in China Town that said they were open until 10:00pm, it was 9:30 and they were all closed. We happened upon this place and they were happy to have us!
author: Bailey F.

description: Service is poor but get the job done had to ask for water 4 times. Food very spicy duh. Very good!
author: Larry B.

description: If you love spicy food, this is the best place in Chinatown for savory, actually-spicy sichuan cuisine. I've come here five or six times with friends and family, and every time, we always get the silky tofu with poke fish and spicy sliced lamb. The décor is nice as well, if that is something you care about. The place is clean and well-decorated, and the tea pots are fun and unique. Definitely a place to eat if you have the time and stomach!
author: Melissa F.

description: This place offers really authentic Sichuan cuisine! The services is great and prompt. We had a group of 18 (Chinese)people there for lunch, and we all loved it. It's in the heart of Chinatown.
author: Mary L.

description: I Love their spicy numbing beef tendon and chicken with explosive chili. SPICY KING is one of my favorite sczchuan restaurant
author: Layla T.

description: The worst service ever! We ordered grill fish in the restaurant. We wait for more than an hour for that dish very patiently. There was another group of people came at the same time with us, their dish came very soon and they ordered the same dish! By the time they finish their lunch, our food is still not ready yet! The waitress keep saying it will come soon for an hour! Then we see another group of people came later than us, they got their grilled fish too! It is ridiculous ! They don't seems care about their service at all!! I don't recommend this place at all!
author: Yun C.

description: loved it! Just ran into this restaurant while visiting Chinatown with my parents. Ordered the xiao guo mi xian and it tastes so good! too spicy too =(. i saw a lot authentic sichuan cuisine on the dinner menu too like pao cai, ya xia ba which won't be seen in most of the Sichuan restaurant in the US
author: Vivian Y.

description: I am a huge fan.  The Szechuan dishes are spicy just as advertised and always taste fresh.   The Ma Po is to die for, although Hot Pot never fails to disappoint either.  The only thing to avoid are the "Chinese restaurant" staples like Kung Pao and Hot-Sour Soup -- not bad, but definitely not the reason to come here.  There's usually a crowd, and the servers don't all speak great English but are (usually) friendly.
author: Christopher S.

description: First time to come to a Szechuan restaurant. The taste satisfied me. The appearance of the cookings is attractive.
author: Young D.

description:
Fantastic spicy Chinese food.  We had the Mongolian beef and the Salt and Pepper prawns.  The prawns are easily the best we have ever had.  Worth the trip!  The Mongolian beef was spicy and amazing!

Quiet small restaurant with good ambiance.  Service was fast.  They take credit card...

Next time we are in downtown we will eat here again!
author: Eric H.

description: Great presentation, excellent Mongolian Beef, and for my not-spicy palate, the chestnut chicken was the best I've ever had and made the best leftovers!  Will definitely be going back.
author: Jamie S.

description: It was good and the line is long. I like it just because it has a shorter wait time than z & y. In all honesty, they all taste the same. Probably because I have Sichuan food too often.
author: Michael Q.

description: Its definitely the best and most typical szchuan food I have ever had at SF. Food is not extremely spicy but just spicy enough to enjoy all the flavors. Highly recommend for who ever looking for real Chinese spicy food!!!
author: Natalie Z.

description: This place is my favorite restaurant for Sichuan food in the Bay Area. The ingredients are always fresh and the preparation really authentic.
author: Liana Z.

description: Nothing good to say. Food was greasy and gross. The service was bad and even the water tasted dirty.
author: Julie F.

description: Soooo terrible customer services! We came around 2:30, when we asked for check our bill, the girl gave our bill back! And we pay in cash! We waited for 15mins, but nobody came to got the change! And one employee just sat next to us had her lunch!
author: Kit G.

description: Good food ... Good atmosphere. Efficient service with a little lack of attention. I had to go in to kitchen to ask for the third time for tea. Got it finally at the end of meal as I was paying the check. But the menu assortment looks like one could come back regularly to enjoy.
author: Liam B.

description: The service was outstanding. Virtually no wait time while inside restaurant. Food was great!
author: Yusuf S.

description: They sat me and my friend in the back near the kitchen. And i saw them dump leftover steamed rice from other peoples dishes back into the ricepot and serve it again to other people. I feel so grossed out
author: Debbie B.

description: This place was recommended to me by a Chinese co-worker. According to her, the best Szechuan cuisine outside of that Chinese region. I tried it and cannot say enough good things about the food and service. I always make it a point to eat here at least once while in San Francisco. I always get the Shredded Pork and Spicy Garlic.
author: Markus B.

description: For the first time, I came here with my family. I didn't expect much. The food was decent. What surprise me was something else. When I got my check, there was service charge (15 percent) was added to my check. I asked why. The server didn't give me clear answer. The owner refused to give me an answer.Usually, I pay tips well. But, this was something else, I never experience like this, especially in Chinese restaurant. I am not sure this things happened to all customer or not. This was weird.
author: In Y.

description:
I chanced upon this restaurant during the Fourth of July weekend when a lot of the dim sum places I wanted to visit were all closed. 

Everything was superb. The lamb left me speechless.

I ordered more food to go. I can't wait to go back. :D
author: MJ C.

description: We usually go a few doors away for delicious salt pepper wings but decided to give this place a try. Ordered Cumin Lamb, 3-Cup Chicken, and stir fried Chinese Broccoli with ginger & garlic. The Cumin Lamb has potential but was too salty. The meat was sliced a little too thin that thus doesnt have as much flavor. Same for the chicken as it was also very salty. It was cubes of boneless chicken thighs served on a miniature wok. If the chef would cut back the salt, I would have given it 4 stars. To achieve 5 stars, they would have to attain a whole new level of seasoning their food. Won't be back as it's not worth the risk of another overly salted food.
author: KL H.

description:
Was in Chinatown with the family and this looked like a nice place to check out. We started off with jasmine tea which was nice, despite being a little bland. 
We shared a large hot and sour soup (more than enough for 5 people). The soup was pipping hot, spicy (this is Szechuan cuisine), balanced, and had a nice touch of cilantro added - defiantly the highlight of the meal.
For the remaining meal we ordered Szechuan beef, green beans, Chinese broccoli, and pork belly. The beef was the weakest part of the meal - although the spiciness level was pretty good, the amount of cornstarch added to the sauce contributed an unappetizing amount of gloupiness. The beans were nice and lightly sauced - nothing special though. The broccoli had a touch of garlic and was surprisingly subtle. The pork belly was the last to arrive - it was 13.99 on the menu and from price alone I would have not guessed it would be an entire pork belly. To be honest, the pork was quite dried out - if you want to be make decent pork belly you need to cook it for a very short time or preferably, for a very long time, which they clearly did not do. The flavor was good though - I manages to reinvigorate the pork by smothering it in the five-spicy sauce. 
The prices were all pretty fair, and the service was fast, though nothing stood out as particularly good. The food tasted a bit msg heavy - I'd say if you're looking for authentic Chinese in Chinatown go elsewhere, but I did find the meal enjoyable and not too heavy.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
Awful. . . 

Judge a place by the amount of people inside and this certainly did not work this time.  Waited for about 30 minutes and spent some time looking at the menu and we decided on the Peking Duck and then afterwards some rice and dishes.  But when we got seated no Peking Duck.  So we ordered some absurdly tasteless (unless HOT is a taste!) beef which was mainly made up of whole chillies, then some Mongolian beef which tasted exactly the same as the other beef, I assume they use the same broth as a taster, and then biggest mistake of all was the sesame chicken which was like candied chicken, I mean inedible candy. . .     the spring onion pancake was the only thing that we ate. .  we don't know about the Chinese broccoli because it never made it to the kitchen, and when I cancelled it the waitress said it was just coming, when I said it was too late, she argued with me that it was ready. . .    then I ordered a beer, quaint, bottles only, no glass. . .  the waiter asked if I wanted another and actually picked up my first bottle and gave it to me to finish. . .   this place is a joke and most of the food was left. . . 

In 35 years of eating out I have never ever not left a tip, this was the exception to the rule, they are so bloody rude here and serve the same old tastless hot muck.

What a waste of one of two nights in SF --

Never again.

There must be better places out there.

AVOID AVOID AVOID
author: Nick M.

description: Service was horrible. I ordered one dish, but received another. I asked them to change it to what I had ordered, but they refused. Did not come back to give us water and gave us the rice after our food was nearly finished.
author: Emilie K.

description: Have been here twice. The first time I was really excited about the food and the authentic Sichuan flavors ... the second time not so impressed. The 2nd time we had a common cold spicy cucumber dish that was not at all prepared how it is supposed to be .. we also ordered La Zi Ji, which had *No bones* and hardly any red peppers ... not at all authentic ..., we may go back to give them another chance.
author: James R.

description: Authentic Szechuan restaurant. Please don't come here and order sweet snd sour pork or fried rice. My favorite dishes here are the single cooked noodle soup, the chicken with explosive peppers, and beef poached with spicy oil and pig intestines (only if you like it). I like my food flaming spicy!!! It is so addictive.
author: Jimmy C.

description: The food was soso.  For the price and quality, Spicy King cannot be compared to Z & Y; the quality at Z & Y is superior and very attentive staff.  At Spicy King, we were charged $1 for a container to take the leftovers.  Waitress and owner ignored our comments.
author: Lcee A.

description: Worst service I have ever experienced. Food was decent but not worth ever coming again.
author: Stephaphanie S.

description: so far the best spicy chinese food i have in the bay area. nice interior... feel very comfortable
author: Frankie I.

description: Amazing.  Decided to try some Szechuan for a change.  It turned out this restaurant has recently changed ownership and at first impressions is absolutely great.  We weren't sure which hot and spicy dishes were the best, so we played it safe and ordered Lemon Chicken and Salt 'n' Pepper Prawns.  I've never had better lemon chicken and the presentation of the prawns (no annoying tail to bite off, either!) in a wooden structure was interesting.  First time I've tried those and they're a lot better than they sound.  Would highly recommend anything here, but if you're like me you won't order the tripe, etc.  Back to the Szechuan specialties.  The gentleman next to me had spicy chicken.  It was in a basket full of chilies and looked really mouth watering. Another table had something in a pot over an open flame.  Next time I'm going to definitely try to be more daring.  Also, they gave us a free order of egg rolls as the prawns came out a matter of five or ten minutes after the chicken.
author: Mark P.

description: Not going to lie I was totally skeptical about eating in china town, China town doesn't look like the cleanest place after all. We went there for the tourist experience but thought why not it's china town we got to have Chinese food. There was a line so I figured it must be good cause there are so many Chinese places to eat so they have competition and they have people waiting so these people must know it's good. Spicy king lives up to its and it lives up to its name its hot but so tasty. Not a fan of their sesame chicken, though a friend at our table loved it. I had the spicy chicken soup I believe, it was so good had normal Spaghetti noodles which made it very good and different but he taste was unbelievable. The only reason 3 stars was it was the worst service we have ever had the language barrier was pretty difficult. She looked annoyed by everything we asks for and had to repeat everything we said like 3 times
author: Bo B.

description: Food was four star, very authentic. Service was poor; two star.  DriedChicken Sautéed w/ Mushroom was mostly bones. Plenty of wonderful flavors.  Would definitely return.
author: David V.

description: I'm no expert on Chinese cuisine, but having lived between China and the bay area for a decade,  I'd say it's about the most "authentic" Chinese food you're going to find in Chinatown. Most other joints cater to tourist tastes: General Tso's chicken, fortune cookies, etc.. To the gentleman from Maine (whitest/least diverse state, not known for its Chinese cuisine) who ordered veggie egg rolls and said "...if you're looking for authentic Chinese in Chinatown go elsewhere...",  I say good luck with that.
author: brian r.

description: Absolutely phenomenal food!!! The best Chinese food I have ever had!!!! The service was great and so is the ambiance.  We absolutely loved everything we ordered.
author: M N.
